HEADLINE: A Different Approach to Raising the Bar

BYLINE: By FRANK LITSKY

DATELINE: SACRAMENTO, July 10 

 BODY:
For years, Toby Stevenson has been different.
 Instead of using his economics degree from Stanford to start a business, which is still a goal, he has become a full-time pole-vaulter. Instead of letting the breeze fly through his hair, he wears a battered hockey helmet. Instead of settling in as a steady but unspectacular competitor, he has vaulted to No. 1 in the world. 
 His improvement has been drastic. Before this year, his career best was 18 feet 10 1/4 inches. Two months ago in Modesto, Calif., he cleared 19-8 1/4. No one else in the world has jumped that high this year, and only seven men have jumped higher. The world record is 20-2 by Sergei Bubka of Ukraine in 1993.
 Stevenson, at 27, is competing in the United States Olympic trials and will face 11 others in the final Sunday night. The top three will qualify for the Olympics next month in Athens.
 In Friday's preliminaries, the 12 who advanced cleared 18- 1/2. Stevenson made it easily, passing on the opening height of 17-8 1/2 and clearing 18- 1/2 on his first attempt. Nick Hysong, the 2000 Olympic champion, qualified, too. Jeff Hartwig, the American-record holder at 19-9 1/4, and Tommy Skipper, the N.C.A.A. champion at 18-8 1/4, did not. Hartwig protested that the vault officials did not give him enough time on one attempt, but the protest was rejected.
 For Hartwig, 36, this was a last hurrah. When asked about future Olympics, he said: ''Absolutely not. No chance.'' For Skipper, a 19-year-old Oregon freshman, there may be better days. For Stevenson, there seems to be an unlimited future.
 ''The last three months have been great,'' Stevenson said. ''I'm superconfident I will make the team, but I say that humbly. If I go to Athens, I will go to medal. I've been putting in four or five hours a day preparing for this. 
 ''I'm not complaining. It's a job, but it's a blast. Whenever the fun dies out, I'm going to stop.''
 That seems a long way off, because Stevenson said he thought he had found the missing part of the puzzle.
 ''I finally figured out how to vault,'' he said. ''I'm not trying to jump like anyone else anymore. Bubka was a great model, but I was taking a part of everyone, and I can't jump like anyone else's jump.''
 Until Stevenson went to Stanford, his only coach was his father, Eddy.
 ''We lived in Odessa, Tex.,'' Stevenson said. ''My dad used to be a vaulter. I think he did 14 feet. When I was in seventh grade, I was doing gymnastics and my dad made me a vaulter.''
 The helmet business started early. There have been serious injuries and deaths to vaulters landing headfirst on a hard runway or a side area.
 ''I wear a roller hockey helmet,'' Stevenson said. ''My parents were looking for one for years. In my senior year in high school, I got this one. The other guys needle me about it all the time, but wearing it is no bother.''
 Stevenson also has the right build for his job. At 6 feet 1 inch and 180 pounds, he has good size for a discipline that requires speed down the runway, power to bend the pole and flexibility to rise and roll over the bar. He is also on a hot streak, and Hartwig, the only American who has ever vaulted higher, is not.
 ''My heart goes out to him,'' Stevenson said of Hartwig. ''Every time you go out, it's a different game. There are no guarantees.'' 
 Hartwig is prone to big-meet mishaps, notably in the 2000 Olympic trials here when he also failed to clear any height in the qualifying round. He took his latest setback calmly.
 ''I've jumped 19 feet in four of my last six meets, but bad things keep happening to me,'' Hartwig said. ''In the grand scheme of things, I'm not going to let this bother me. This is a small part of my career in this sport.''
 Pole-vaulters have their ups and downs in more ways than one. As Hartwig said of Stevenson, ''He's running well and his technique is very sound, but he still has to execute the jump in the final the way he has all year.''
 Stevenson knows well the perils he avoided in the preliminaries here and the dangers he faces in Sunday's final.
 ''The Olympic trials are the worst meet you'll ever have,'' he said.

HEADLINE: That High-Tech Balloon Is Going Ssssssssss

BYLINE: By GRETCHEN MORGENSON

 BODY:
THE warnings from technology companies came fast and furious last week, cuffing investors who had bought their shares on hopes of super earnings generated in a hot economy. Individual investors and hedge funds alike had piled into tech stocks and enjoyed the ride through 2003, convinced that 2004 results would justify the shares' soaring prices.
 But with software companies like Siebel Systems and Veritas Software, hardware companies like Unisys and computer resellers like the CDW Corporation and Ingram Micro Inc. cautioning that their businesses softened in the second quarter, the sound of air escaping a balloon is more than detectable.
 Inquiring investors want to know: Is this a blip, or is the second-quarter slowdown the beginning of a longer-term malaise in tech? 
 Fred Hickey, editor of The High-Tech Strategist in Nashua, N.H., and a technology stock analyst who knows the industry down to its nittiest and grittiest, says the setbacks in the sector are just beginning. 
 Investors may have been lulled into thinking that the second-quarter results at tech companies would be sunny because reports of shortfalls had been relatively rare. 
 Companies typically alert investors to problems late in a quarter, but by June 30, that front was quiet. ''Normally the third month in a quarter belongs to the confessors,'' Mr. Hickey said. But at the end of June, he added ''there were more positive preannouncements than negative.''
 Nevertheless, two signs point to problems ahead for technology stocks, he said. First, semiconductor shares, which often lead the action in tech stocks, have gone into a nose dive. The semiconductor stock index, known as the SOX, is down 11.2 percent this year, and spot prices of computer chips are forecasting further declines. 
 But the biggest trouble spots on Mr. Hickey's horizon are the ballooning inventories on tech companies' balance sheets. Already rising in the first quarter, these inventories will probably show a surge for the second quarter, he said, because few tech companies appear to have cut production in recent months.
 Investors may not have noticed how inventories have grown at some of their favorite technology concerns. After all, balance sheets are boring; income statements make for much jazzier reading. And comparing balance-sheet items in quarterly reports requires some work: most show only assets and liabilities from the current and previous quarter, not from the same quarter during the previous year. 
 IN the first quarter of 2004, inventories jumped 21 percent to 61 percent, year over year, at such tech stalwarts as Dell, Cisco Systems, Intel and Texas Instruments. And that was when the economy was cooking. So Mr. Hickey expects inventories to show a surge for the second quarter. When inventories rocket, profit margins are hurt. Hefty write-downs are another common result.
 The sales shortfalls at some technology companies will become most evident in the third quarter, Mr. Hickey said, making for some very ugly earnings comparisons from the same period in 2003. Back then, tax rebates were propelling consumers into the stores and gross domestic product soared 8 percent, annualized. Computer notebook sales in the third quarter of 2003, for example, were up 60 percent. 
 But this year, personal computer sales in the United States are growing at rates in the single digits or low teens. PC and notebook sales are also slowing in Europe and are actually declining in Japan. 
 In addition, the tax rebates, courtesy of the White House, are spent, mortgage refinancings have peaked and rising oil prices are pinching consumers. So it's no wonder that sales of tech gear have slowed. 
 Mr. Hickey said the inventory situation at some of the nation's biggest technology companies reminds him of late 2000, when demand from nascent Internet companies screeched to a halt. Although it became apparent in March 2000 that the Internet boom, created in part by a profligate Wall Street, was over, the impact of this steep decline in demand did not show up in major suppliers' results until much later that year and in early 2001. 
 ''This industry is hopelessly optimistic,'' Mr. Hickey said. ''They always overproduce.''
 None of this would matter if technology shares were cheap. But they are not. The price-to-earnings ratio on both Dell and Cisco is 32. Texas Instruments' is 30, and Intel's is 26. 
 ''On June 30, the bulls were extremely long and vulnerable, even though underneath the surface there was a lot of trouble in a lot of places,'' Mr. Hickey said.
 Perhaps the companies issuing early warnings recently will prove to be in the minority by the time all second-quarter results are out. But technology has had a heck of a run in the past year. As they say, nobody ever went broke taking profits.

Monthly sales reports from the company have shown a decline in sales growth; the company did not warn of a decline.

HEADLINE: Transit Hub Seen as Important Advance

BYLINE: By ELSA BRENNER

DATELINE: NEW ROCHELLE 

 BODY:
A $20.5 MILLION transportation hub opened here about a month ago with parking for 920 cars and bus, train and taxi connections to Manhattan and other cities. Planners say the project is a critical addition in an area of this southern Westchester city that has been experiencing a revival of housing and commerce.
 The new five-story structure is connected by a footpath to a century-old Metro-North Railroad station next door and by access roads to the New England Thruway, directly to the west, which carries about 21.4 million vehicles a year through Westchester.
 Built with $13 million from the Federal Transit Administration, $4.5 million from the state and $3 in city money, the new concrete-and-brick center has 800 parking spaces for permit holders, 102 metered spaces for daily use and 18 spaces for those with handicaps. 
 Its ground level houses a terminal for an estimated 350 buses a day on the county's Bee-Line system, which serves all of Westchester, said John B. Clemente, the city's engineer.
 When the terminal opens after Labor Day, it will also be used by private long-distance bus carriers like Greyhound and ShortLines, by limousine companies offering connections to regional airports and by local taxis.
 What sets this transportation hub apart from others is that it has been built by a city as opposed to a transportation agency, said Tim Tracy, vice president of Desman Associates, an architectural and engineering firm in Manhattan that has designed about 20 such centers throughout the country. The firm worked with the Long Island Rail Road last year on a similar structure with 400 parking spaces in Long Beach, and it is designing another larger hub in Mineola for the agency.
 Working with Metro-North Railroad two years ago, it drew up plans for a hub that was built in Poughkeepsie. And it is designing three such intermodal centers -- as the transportation depots are often called by governments and architects -- for New Jersey Transit.
 ''Increasingly, agencies and governments are looking for alternatives because of the congestion on roadways from cars,'' Mr. Tracy said. ''We do these all across the country, especially where cities are growing or re-growing.''
 The downtown of New Rochelle, a city of about 72,000 people on Long Island Sound, declined during the last half of the 20th century, with shoppers forsaking the business district for suburban shopping malls. In recent years, however, the city has begun to experience a rebirth.
 Several years ago, Cappelli Enterprises of Valhalla built New Roc City, a 1.2-million-square-foot family-entertainment center, with a skating rink, movie theaters and an arcade, among other things. Close by, AvalonBay Communities erected a 412-unit luxury apartment tower. In addition, developers recently spent $15 million to convert a former five-story Bloomingdale's in the downtown to 72 market-rate work-live condominium lofts. 
 Looking ahead, AvalonBay has submitted plans to build a second apartment building, and Cappelli Enterprises is considering office or residential construction next to New Roc City. Meanwhile, a business improvement district in the downtown is promoting other new residential and commercial development.
 At the Regional Plan Association, a nonprofit civic planning and advocacy group in New York City, Jeffrey M. Zupan, a senior fellow for transportation, described the new intermodal center and the development around it as ''mutually supportive.''
 The new transportation hub, in the works for more than a decade, was scheduled to open this past winter. But inclement winter weather delayed construction, according to George F. Ranione, the city's public properties and parking manager. It is now opening in phases. 
 The permit-parking section opened early last month, with the city charging $750 a year for each space. All of the permits were spoken for by the time the garage opened, Mr. Ranione said. Because state and federal funds were used to finance the project, the permits were not limited to New Rochelle residents. 
 Additional spaces are available at 75 cents an hour for nonpermit holders, although that section of the garage will not open until later this summer, when a meter system is installed.
 To coordinate the new structure with its surroundings, the architects used brick and ornamental iron, Mr. Tracy said. Brick is found on many of New Rochelle's older structures, and decorative iron can be seen on the foot bridges at the railroad station next door to the transportation center. 
 Even though the wood-frame station has been connected to the new structure, only minimal improvements are planned there, because New Rochelle has requested that the depot be listed on the National Register of Historic Places.
 Built in the late 1800's, when the area was a favorite summer spot for New York City dwellers, the station, which is owned by the city, serves travelers on Metro-North's New Haven line. It is also the only Westchester stop on Amtrak's high-speed Northeast corridor service from Boston to Newport News, Va. (Inside the station, bathrooms are being upgraded, and a newspaper concession is being expanded.) 
 Because the transportation hub will be open at all hours, video surveillance cameras have been installed with links to local police stations. In addition, the brightly lit stairwells have glass walls, as do the elevators. ''For security reasons,'' Mr. Tracy explained, ''people need to see out as well as in.''

HEADLINE: First Thing We Do, Let's Seat All the Lawyers

BYLINE: By JASON ZINOMAN

 BODY:
ON July 1, 100 lawyers and summer associates from Skadden, Arps, Slate, Meagher & Flom rolled up their sleeves and headed to the Delacorte Theater in Central Park for an evening of culture. After finishing off a buffet dinner backstage, next to Turtle Pond, the conservatively dressed crowd adjourned to the theater itself, where reserved seats to a preview of ''Much Ado About Nothing'' were awaiting them. The firm's bill was $10,000.
 Hold on. Reserved seats for law firms certainly doesn't sound like the democratic vision of Joseph Papp, the founder of ''free Shakespeare'' in Central Park. Papp, after all, said that his theater should be as inclusive as the public library. Isn't free Shakespeare in the park supposed to be, well, free? 
 Since its inception, the Public Theater's presence in Central Park has grown from a utopian idea into a widely sponsored New York tradition -- yet one that has become somewhat tarnished over the last two years, as the schedule of shows has been reduced to one per summer. Moreover, recent productions have received mixed critical marks at best; the consensus is that they suffered from weak performances by celebrities who appeared to have been cast for their names, not their talent. New York Times reviews complain, for example, about senseless high concepts, lame gimmicks and, perhaps most of all, wrong-headed casting, whether it be Julia Stiles as Viola in ''Twelfth Night'' in 2002 or Natalie Portman as Nina in ''The Seagull'' in 2001. 
 Last year, Ben Brantley, the chief theater critic of The Times, described the production of ''Henry V'' at the Delacorte as ''one long, desperate exercise in diversionary tactics.'' In 2002, he wrote that ''Twelfth Night'' was ''seriously confused.'' And while he praised Meryl Streep and Kevin Kline in that 2001 production of ''The Seagull'' for providing sparks of electricity, he added that they ''rarely connect into a circuit.''
 ''On the Town'' was the last show at the Delacorte to move to Broadway when it transferred to the Gershwin Theater in 1998 (and lost $8 million). The jury is still out on the new production of ''Much Ado About Nothing,'' which opens on Tuesday, directed by David Esbjornson and starring Kristen Johnston and Jimmy Smits as Beatrice and Benedick and Sam Waterston as the king, Leonato. Should critics judge the production a success, it is still unlikely that the play would move to Broadway. The shows with commercial potential at the Public Theater now emerge from its downtown home, which the theater acquired in 1966.
 ''The heart of the organization is now at Lafayette Street,'' said Robert Marx, the vice president of the Fan Fox and Leslie R. Samuels Foundation, which gave $25,000 to the Public Theater in 2003. ''The Delacorte is just an ancillary project.''
 The theater's latest official name seems to reflect this shift away from Shakespeare and the summer productions in the park. Founded as the Shakespeare Workshop in 1954, the theater later became known as the New York Shakespeare Festival. That name was slowly phased out, until it was replaced last year by that of the Public Theater.
 Originally, the Shakespeare Festival presented three productions in the park each summer. But the schedule has been trimmed over the years because of the financial challenges in producing free theater. In 1975, the Public started producing only two shows, which was fairly standard for 17 years. In 2002 the Public cut its park offerings to one show (while increasing the length of the run from four to seven weeks). City budget cuts and the effects of the post-9/11 economy were cited among the reasons for this move, but, surely, the box office failures of its Broadway productions ''On the Town'' and ''The Wild Party'' didn't help either.
 All of which means the Public Theater may soon reassess its summer strategy. In February, the theater's longtime producer, George C. Wolfe, announced that he would be resigning; his replacement, who has not been named, is expected in the fall. But Mara Manus, the executive director, has already begun retooling the Public's program at the park. First off, she has aggressively sought to sell to more investors and sponsors (otherwise known as ticket buyers).
 When Ms. Manus arrived in 2002, she was dismayed, she said recently, at how the ticket programs had been promoted. ''The culture at the Public when I got here was, 'Oh, we don't want to look too commercial,' '' she said. ''But there were people of means who didn't want to stand in line who didn't know about this.''
 She was quick to add that the program for individuals to buy tickets has a long history at the Public Theater. ''Joe Papp did this first and aggressively promoted it,'' she said.
 In 1960, Papp established the audience sponsor program, the first of many euphemisms that the Public Theater would employ to avoid words with commercial undertones like ''ticket'' and ''sale.'' In her biography ''Joe Papp: An American Life,'' Helen Epstein writes that there was an impassioned debate among the board of trustees at the time about the program, which was essentially a subscription plan (three shows for $7.50). But Papp -- who made his name by waging war in the press and the courts with Robert Moses, the much-feared parks commissioner, over admission fees (Moses wanted them; Papp did not) -- insisted it was necessary for the theater to survive.
 This year, Ms. Manus tried to publicize the summer sponsor program with a campaign of print advertisements, e-mail messages and a mailing; sponsors receive a reserved seat in exchange for a $100 contribution. It is paying off, she said. Already, the Public has signed up more sponsors than the 3,747 total last year. Ms. Manus put the goal at 6,000 (some will receive discounts because of types of purchase) before the end of the summer. In addition, 47 businesses (the vast majority are law firms) have each contributed up to $10,000 for blocks of tickets. Ms. Manus said the Public would cap sales of reserved seats at one quarter of the Delacorte audience. The theater holds 1,900 seats. If attained, that means for those who acquire tickets the traditional way -- sweating it out in line -- up to 19,950 of the total 79,800 seats to be occupied this summer will not be available.
 Of the $1.9 million cost of mounting ''Much Ado About Nothing'' (which includes $700,000 for indirect costs, like staff salaries and upkeep of the Delacorte), the summer sponsor program accounts for 19 percent of income. The remainder derives from foundations (24 percent), corporate donations (21 percent, which includes cash or in-kind giving by companies like J. P. Morgan and The New York Times) and the blocks of Delacorte tickets sold to businesses (16 percent). There is still a 20 percent shortfall.
 ''Free theater is a nice idea, but it's not a practical one,'' said Adrian Benepe, the commissioner of the city's Department of Parks and Recreation, who is an ex officio member of the Public's board. ''Groups need to become increasingly creative to fund something like free Shakespeare.''
 Some longtime supporters of the Public Theater thought the leadership became a little too creative when it announced a trial run of the Joe's Pub in the Park series this summer. Ms. Manus described the nine cabaretlike performances over nearly two weeks (Aug. 16 to 27) as an effort to augment its summer schedule. To support this new venture, the Public will charge admission at the Delacorte for five of the nine performances.
 ''Joe would not have agreed with this,'' said Merle Debuskey, a retired press agent who represented the Public Theater at its inception and for many years thereafter. ''It's a radical change from the founding philosophy of this theater.''
 Mr. Marx agreed. ''This may not seem like much -- just a few concerts -- but it opens the door,'' he said. ''People have lost sight of the fact that the Public was not just about producing plays. It was a civic dream.''
 But such grumbling has taken place outside the walls of the Public Theater. Unlike the debate at the time the sponsor program was instituted, there was little argument this time among the trustees. ''There were questions among the board about how this would be perceived,'' said Ms. Manus, who insisted that the policy of providing free tickets to Shakespeare plays at the Delacorte would not change. ''But I think everyone agreed that we needed to extend our programming.''
 Ms. Manus emphasized that the Joe's Pub series is not a replacement for a second summer show in the park. It has more to do, she said, with luring the young, hip audience at Joe's Pub to the Delacorte and, it is hoped, to future Shakespeare productions there and eventually to other productions at the Public Theater itself.
 Shakespeare in the Park may have been a radical idea in Joseph Papp's day, but since then small companies have arisen to provide some competition. Earlier this month, for example, you could see free and outdoor versions of ''Measure for Measure'' at La Plaza Cultural in the East Village, ''The Merry Wives of Windsor'' in Central Park, near the Bethesda Fountain, and ''A Midsummer Night's Dream,'' in a Lower East Side parking lot for the 10th anniversary production of Shakespeare in the Parking Lot.
 Whoever replaces Mr. Wolfe as producer of the Public Theater will have the benefit, Ms. Manus said, of inheriting stable financial conditions. According to her projections, the Public, with an annual budget of $12 million, will be in the black by the end of the summer for the first time since 1998. Now may be the perfect time to take a fresh look at Shakespeare in Central Park.
 Early conversations among the Public's leadership about the theater's 50th-anniversary offerings next year at the Delacorte suggest what may be a return to the theater's roots. Most encouragingly to many people, the Public will produce a second show that summer, along with the previously announced production of ''A Midsummer Night's Dream,'' to be directed by Mr. Wolfe. Ms. Manus said the second work may be a revival of a classic musical. (The 1997 revival of ''On the Town'' was the last musical the Public produced at the Delacorte.)
 In addition, there have been discussions about bringing back the mobile theater, Papp's long-defunct traveling stage that brought Shakespeare to the five boroughs. ''I don't think we're going to show traditional Shakespeare,'' Ms. Manus said of the work presented in the mobile theater. ''It could be a musical adaptation of Shakespeare. It might be something bilingual.''
 How will these new financial burdens be supported? ''Scenarios are being looked into,'' Ms. Manus said coyly.
 Joseph Papp's widow, Gail Papp, who sits on the board, put it another way: ''It's the same as always. We really have to invent ways to make money.''

He is governor, not king.

HEADLINE: University Land Grab

 BODY:

To the Editor:
 Re ''Stony Brook Trying to Seize Land'' (June 27):
 I attended two meetings concerning SUNY Stony Brook's attempt to condemn 246 acres owned by the Gyrodyne Company of North America. I learned that the university intends to use the land to build 10 ''incubators'' -- buildings that will be rented to small, presumably high-tech businesses. In other words, the state university will serve as the landlord for private companies.
 Am I correct in concluding, then, that our state government is now legally able to condemn privately held land (Gyrodyne's), pay for it with public funds, develop it with public funds and then open it for use by private businesses, which will surely pay discounted rent? And all of this will happen in a residential neighborhood, which will surely suffer economic and environmental damage? The university is putting its presumably prestigious face on corporate welfare, but this time, even the law seems forgotten.

Vicki Janik
Stony Brook

HEADLINE: Nets Stadium? Not So Fast

 BODY:

To the Editor:
 With regard to your call for a ''truly independent examination'' on the Brooklyn Nets arena proposal, I would like to emphasize that the economic analysis produced by Gustav Peebles and me was done independently and without payment. Furthermore, a third-party analysis would represent only one step in a comprehensive review process.
 Your editorial does not seem to recognize that there are other development options for both the Atlantic Yards and the Far West Side. The choices are not limited to a sports arena versus no development at all. A thorough review would consult the public, draw competitive proposals and account for all possible development alternatives, including ones in the case of the Atlantic Yards that do not require the use of eminent domain.
 Forest City Ratner's own data show the arena to be a money-loser, and anyone in the real estate field would recognize the scheme's office component as highly speculative. And yet we are asked to hand over hundreds of millions in subsidies without exploring options that could be both more profitable for the developer and beneficial to the community.
 It is a sad statement on how the State of New York conducts its business that a major paper like The Times does not view eminent domain as an extreme measure.

JUNG KIM
Bronx

LENGTH: 293 words

HEADLINE: 'Smart Growth' and Soccer Moms

 BODY:

To the Editor:
 Your June 27 articles ''Transit by Pedal or Foot'' and ''Changing the Face of Real Estate Developments'' both point out pros and cons of the use of the term ''smart growth'' -- good if it is true to its name regarding sustainability, bad if it is used in name only, to ''sell'' a development project that is contrary to issues of sustainability.
 I have heard Lee E. Koppelman, the executive director of the Long Island Regional Planning Board, say to beware of the term, saying ''there is only good planning and bad planning.''
 It would be valuable for critics to actually provide the public with the definition of ''smart growth.'' For instance, the frequently suggested linkage of ''smart growth'' with ''new urbanism'' is questionable. New urbanism, while claiming to be traditional planning, typically proposes development projects on open ''green'' sites. Thus they take away open space for new automobile-oriented residential enclaves.
 I believe that there is an entirely opposite smart growth potential of revitalizing existing towns and villages with the same program of new higher density residential zoning on and adjacent to existing ''main streets.'' Walking to work, adaptive re-use of existing buildings and making undeveloped land into ''green belt'' parkland are undeniably ''smart growth'' and fundamental to sustainability.
 Almost all the older existing towns on the north and south shore and some of the newer ones in between could be revitalized into wonderful places to live, work and visit. This is not new; in fact it is ''old urbanism,'' the way cities have evolved for centuries.

Jon Michael Schwarting
Port Jefferson

The writer is director, graduate program in urban and regional design, New York Institute of Technology.

HEADLINE: Sex, Race and the City

BYLINE: By Tessa Hadley. 
Tessa Hadley is the author of two novels, ''Accidents in the Home'' and ''Everything Will Be All Right.''

 BODY:

COUNTRY OF ORIGIN
By Don Lee.
315 pp. W. W. Norton & Company. $24.95.
 THE central preoccupations of Don Lee's first novel feel like urgent issues for our times. The characters wrestle with slippery questions of race and identity, and the story unfolds in that liminal space where America interacts with another culture. Here it is Japan: a white-looking young American woman named Lisa Countryman disappears in 1980 into the underworld of Tokyo's sex trade. All the cliches that formula might evoke -- wholesome American girl lost to the unfathomable corruptions of the Oriental Other -- are complicated in this novel, however, and in the end flipped upside down. Lisa is in fact neither white nor straightforwardly American; and it is her quest for her ''real'' origins that has led her into danger. The truth about what has happened to her turns out to be comic-grotesque rather than tragic-poignant, and has more to do with her own angst and longings than with the machinations of any evil exploiter. 
 Rather than constructing the plot of ''Country of Origin'' around the conventional thriller certainties of us and them, Don Lee -- he is the longtime editor of the literary journal Ploughshares and the author of ''Yellow,'' a story collection -- insists we become aware of the complex and shifting bases for our identity and our behavior. At first glance the world of this novel seems polarized between the American community, centered on the United States Embassy, and a busy, economically buoyant Tokyo. The Americans are assertively individualistic, the Japanese a conformist community hidebound by tradition. Beneath the surface of American confidence, though, lurks extraordinary anxiety about identity. Tom Hurley, the young official assigned to Lisa's case, is half-white and half-Korean, but he habitually lies and says he's Hawaiian, ''a declaration of racial neutrality.'' Harmless enough: but the lies, once they've begun, accumulate. 
 When Tom begins an affair with Julia, the American wife of a Japanese C.I.A. operative also attached to the embassy, he can't stop himself from telling her, falsely, that in Hawaii he was a top surfer and that he is a graduate of U.C.L.A. Meanwhile, Julia lets him believe, wrongly, in the old-money, private-school image she projects. When Lisa Countryman's sister arrives in Tokyo, everyone involved in investigating the disappearance is thrown by the discovery that she's black; Lisa turns out to be adopted and half-black, half-Korean. Tom's fellow officers at the embassy -- Benny, who is black, and Jorge, who is Chicano -- grumble endlessly (and, the novel suggests, with some justification) about how their race prevents them from getting promoted. In this novel's American melting pot, racial identities stubbornly persist, and matter; on the other hand, they can't offer a definitive account of who anyone is. Tom is used to being asked, ''Where are you from?'' and ''What are you?'' This is code, he believes, for ''You don't look like a real American.'' 
 The labyrinthine conventions that govern Japanese society start to seem fairly transparent by comparison -- although there's no sentimentality about those, either. Lee stresses the unapologetic, institutionalized racial exclusivity of the Japanese, from high school girls giggling at an African on the subway to a maternity nurse's casual talk of how mixed-race babies have ''polluted'' the planet. The Japanese words scattered in Lee's prose habituate the reader to a Japanese perception of whites as dubious gaijin who emanate a ''butter stink'' from eating too much dairy. Kenzo Ota, perhaps the most sympathetic of the central characters, is a conventional enough middle-aged Japanese detective, longing to be moved from his shaming position at the dreaded window desk in the office, wishing he weren't stamped as a loser by the stigma of divorce. Whether he likes it or not, however, he's an embodiment of a Japan in the throes of profound change. 
 There's a touching moment when Kenzo burns a bundle of reeds on the walkway outside his apartment, a residual gesture that halfheartedly stands in for the full ritual of the Buddhist Festival of the Dead; it's not worth going home to the city of his ancestors because he doesn't know anyone there anymore. He's mistaken, too, about the identity of a boy he thinks must be his son. In Japan, as in America, identity is being shaken loose from traditional moorings. Kenzo's obsession with noise -- he changes apartments to get away from the whir of an air-conditioner, only to find himself tormented by the grinding motor of his new refrigerator -- reflects his quest for a lost perfect peace and wholeness that can't really exist any longer in his contemporary troubled city.
 ''Country of Origin'' doesn't altogether deliver on the promise of this interesting material. It has all the right ingredients for a thriller: a missing girl, a variety of suspects, two men on the case, entanglements in high places and a tour through some of the more bizarre aspects of the Tokyo sex trade. It's a good idea structurally, too, that the account of Lisa's months in Japan leading up to her disappearance is woven into the narrative of the search for her; this takes us into some fascinating locales and also underscores our urgent need to find out what has happened to her. But the unraveling plot isn't built with the right degree of ingenious tight fit. The few surprises aren't surprising or convincing enough; the final twist in Lisa's search for her roots, a nice curiosity in itself, doesn't feel adequately momentous to carry, as it must, the emotional weight of our loss and our discovery. 
 Lee never quite finds a comfortable register for the novel's language, which has a secondhand, superficial quality: ''She had never had the audience of such an elegant, good-looking man before, and the wonderful thing was that he seemed interested in her.'' And there is not much evidence of an effort to remake perception freshly in words. People walk off ''briskly,'' Julia's singing performance is ''rousing'' and ''soulful'' and at the end of it Tom is ''already half in love with her.'' This isn't a genre narrative where well-worn phrases become a stylistic choice; the sentences instead seem slack and loose. Whatever power a novel has to move us, and to make us think, depends on the power of the exact words chosen. 


GRAPHIC: Photo: Don Lee, whose characters wrestle with questions of race and identity in his first novel, ''Country of Origin.'' (Photograph by Michelle McDonald)
