HEADLINE: Summertime at P.S. 1: Where Opposites Like Hands On/Hands Off Attract

BYLINE: By ROBERTA SMITH

 BODY:
Summer doesn't lull much at P.S. 1 Contemporary Art Center in Long Island City, Queens, especially since the venerable alternative space became an affiliate of the Museum of Modern Art in 2000. On Saturdays, at least, the place teems with people, thanks to the center's summer Warm Up series, which features a D.J. spinning music at the top of the building's wide steps from 3 to 9 p.m. This event predictably fills the courtyard with several thousand of the city's young and youthful, who come to listen, dance, see, be seen and get convivial. 
 Part of the fun is the courtyard's latest architectural folly, designed each summer by the winner of the MoMA/P.S. 1 Young Architects Program. The basic requirements are shade, water, bar facilities and lounging options. Wading pools, mist machines and sunning or dancing platforms are usual factors. The 2004 winner, nARCHITECTS, has designed ''Canopy,'' a beautiful bamboo structure that reaches over the wall between the big and smaller courtyards like the skeleton of an undulating worm. It is too spindly and transparent to provide much shade, but it is exceptionally beautiful as sculpture, especially when viewed from one of the many windows. 
 Indoors, things are also jumping, more so than usual. The current exhibitions and artists' projects have an unusually high rate of memorable moments and together reflect the current state of contemporary art as usefully as a Whitney Biennial. 
 Two big theme shows define the spectrum: ''Hard Light'' and ''Curious Crystals of Unusual Purity,'' which fittingly hold down opposite ends of P.S. 1's third floor. Assuming that all dichotomies are false, but some less false than others, these shows could be said to represent the main polar opposites of our moment, which could be described as ''Camera/No Camera'' or, if you prefer, ''Mechanical/Hands On.''

'Hard Light'
 The Camera/Mechanical position is firmly held by ''Hard Light,'' an exhibition of video, photography and installations by nine artists organized by P.S. 1's chief curator, Klaus Biesenbach, in collaboration with the artist Doug Aitken. This is a good show, but also an unbalanced one. Mr. Aitken's ''Interiors,'' a large and ambitious 2002 installation involving three big video projections in a T-shaped structure made of 11 screens, has pride of place in the show's big central gallery. Combined with his billing as co-curator, the size and placement of his piece tend to make everything else seem a little ancillary. 
 Don't get me wrong. Despite its lopsidedness, the show has strength. It includes contemporary works by Ugo Rondinone, Fischli/Weiss and Carsten Holler, with historical backup provided by a Bruce Nauman corridor, the storyboards for Chris Marker's classic underground film ''La Jetee'' (1962), and the preparatory materials for ''Hard Light,'' a 1978 book of photographs and text by Lawrence Weiner and Ed Ruscha.
 Taken as a whole, the show raises interesting ideas about narrative, architecture, landscape and the perception of space and light, all the while combining a rather cold factualness with various forms of glamour, whether it is the industrial fabrication of ''Atomium Phi,'' Mr. Holler's blinking-light sculpture; the floor-to-ceiling hanging of misty ocean views (populated or not by one of two attractive young women) that is Mr. Rondinone's ''Sleep''; or the physical aggressiveness of Mr. Nauman's ''Green Light Corridor.'' In this well-known 1970 installation, the visitor squeezes between two walls 40 feet long and 12 inches apart, a slice of space made stranger by fluorescent green lights. 
 But arrayed in galleries that surround the big one holding Mr. Aitken's ''Interiors,'' these works suffer from an all-roads-lead-to-Rome problem. They seem to be included primarily to isolate one of the qualities or elements that Mr. Aitken brings together quite effectively in ''Interiors,'' which means that the show can sometimes seem like a form of mutual homage, in which Mr. Aitken acknowledges valued influences and colleagues while outshining their reflected glory. 
 Mr. Aitken gets away with this because ''Interiors'' is exceptionally good. It develops ideas about narrative, sound and space (both social and volumetric) that were already interesting in his ''Electric Earth'' of 1999. (That piece was memorable in both the 2001 Venice Biennale and the 2002 Whitney Biennial, and was acquired by the Whitney.) 
 The interiors of the work's title would seem to be human ones, the place in each person where thoughts, dreams, passions and particular talents reside and build toward outward expression. In effect, Mr. Aitken's camera follows four individuals from inside to outside, from pensive pent-up energy to energy unleashed in a way that involves speed and sound. Each sequence starts out quietly, the individuals wander through their lives and various settings -- natural, industrial and postindustrial.
 But soon each is revealed to be a kind of specialist -- an artist if you will. A woman turns out to be a fierce handball player, a man seems to be one of the world's fastest rappers (he is Andre Benjamin of OutKast) and a worker in a helicopter factory demonstrates an equally rapid-fire proficiency as a tap dancer. A quiet Japanese man who rehearses in what seems to be an empty lecture hall is an auctioneer at the famous Tokyo fish market.
 These four narratives shift constantly among the three screens, with Mr. Aitken's editing gaining pace as his subjects begin to manifest their special skills. The work periodically builds into a cacophony of speeding-up close-ups and loud percussive rhythms, sounds spoken, tapped, grunted or thwacked by one person acting alone, making his or her presence known. 

'Curious Crystals'
 This sprawling group show, which has been organized by Bob Nikas, P.S. 1's curatorial adviser, with Steve Lafreniere, a D.J., writer and editor at Index magazine, as guest curator, speaks for the continued thrills of hands-on, mostly camera-free objectmaking. With more than 100 works by 36 artists, it was inspired by the idea of the wunderkammer, the displays of earthly delights -- both natural and manmade -- assembled by rich collectors, scholars and princes beginning in the 15th and 16th centuries. They were in a way the aesthete's response to the Age of Discovery. 
 To my eye, the show is actually a little short on wondrous sights as far as individual artworks are concerned. But the curators have proceeded with the deliberation and thought that is something of a trademark in Nikas exhibitions. The show is a tightly woven affair with each piece is locked in close dialog with those around it, usually on several levels, despite frequent shifts in style and subject and medium.
 One minute you're looking at Jeff Davis's drawings of minuscule homoerotic figures, the next at ''Glimmerer,'' an abstract installation/wall painting by Lisa Beck that actively lives up to its name. At another point you'll proceed from Amy Gartell's hallucinatory rock-posterish drawings to Michelle Segre's sculptures of brightly hued mutant cacti, or from Ara Peterson's ''Vision Master,'' an optical black and white DVD that resembles an animated Bridget Riley, to an equally optically strange painting by John Trembley. 
 Wonder, of course, involves an ele
ment of surprise and unexpectedness, so it makes sense that quite a few of the works here are unfamiliar and that none of the artists match the star status of those in ''Hard Light.'' Most are emerging, re-emerging or underknown. Some, like the abstract painter Peter Young, haven't been heard from in years; others, like Harry Smith, have only been recently resurrected; and still others, like Bruce Conner, are reclusive. 
 To a certain extent this is more a curator's than an artist's show. But if taken slowly, one object at a time, while attending to the implied bridges between works, this show will win you over or wear you down. Either way you will emerge with a new understanding that something strange, wonderful and quasi-visionary lurks beneath the surface of all kinds of art. 

Lee Lozano
 The first retrospective devoted to the New York artist Lee Lozano, who died in 1999 at 68, is an angry, often engaging affair. Lozano certainly had her weaknesses as an artist, but when economically expressed, satiric rage can have its own kind of cartoonish force, and this force runs through just about everything she did. The show, ''Drawn From Life, 1961-71,'' begins with acerbic paintings and drawings of enormous battling tools that both borrow from and parody the masculine swagger of Abstract Expressionism.
 In one work a wrench and a claw hammer go at it; in another, drill bits and razor blades clash. In a series of graphite and crayon drawings, these tools become increasingly vocal and obscene and gradually mutate into body parts and orifices. Then, in the late 1960's, the work suddenly succumbs to Minimalism and goes relatively mute. The first works are monochromatic canvases that are perforated with circles or, in one case, a grid of round-cornered squares. These are followed by a series of beautifully crafted if rather generic works involving shaded monochromatic forms, shafts and orbs that still have some of the sexual force of the drawings. 
 At the show's end, Lozano's savage wit lies in ambush, this time in a series of drawings and written notes documenting private performance pieces, including ''Masturbation Piece,'' ''Grass Piece'' and the ''No Grass Piece.'' One work states: ''I offer to think about something for anyone.'' Regardless of what you think of the actual art objects, Lozano's slightly unhinged raucous anger will ring in your ears.

Smaller Shows
 The dualities of the larger shows are reflected in the smaller ones, nearly all of which deserve attention. Several exhibitions with photography, video or sound might almost be extensions of ''Hard Light,'' in a softer sort of way, while aggressively physical works continue the hand-made emphasis of ''Curious Crystals.'' 
 With its live feed from cities around the world and its sci-fi-noir, postcardlike snippets of spoken text, ''Time Deferred on Cancellation,'' by the German-born, New York-based artist Jenny Vogel operates in the same orbit as Mr. Rondinone's and Fischli/Weiss's contributions to ''Hard Light.'' So does the exhibition of photographic and slide projection works by the Los Angeles-based artist and critic Walead Beshty, whose photographs of vacant shopping centers, ''Dead Malls,'' manages to be both mordant and sad.
 The sense of cultural decline can be found in the gap between the nocturnal photographs of the photographer William Gedney (1933-1989), taken during cross-country trips between 1965 and 1975, with those taken by the painter Christopher Wool in New York City's Chinatown and Lower East Side in the late 1990's. Ryan McGinley's large nocturnal photographs of nubile, usually naked adolescents romping in trees, fields and streams echo the wan romanticism of Mr. Rondinone's work.
 ''Avanti Popolo,'' an exercise in simultaneous sound by the Sarajevo-born but Paris-based artist Maja Bajevic, consists of the national anthems of 30 countries playing on sound systems crowded in one gallery. It creates the uneasy feeling that the world will never ''just get along,'' as Rodney King put it.
 Materiality reigns one way or another in Johnston Foster's installation ''Permanent Vacation,'' an adamantly determined landscape environment, made mostly of foam rubber and vinyl, that is more interesting than its featured inhabitants, four ghosts in a hot tub; and the more free-style sculpture by the Brazilian artist Marepe, involving a tub full of Styrofoam cups that the viewer can churn. 
 The most imposing installation is Phoebe Washburn's ''Seconds of Something,'' in which obsessive recycling is manifested by a room-size ramp cobbled from found wood scraps and huge but not thick rolls of pasted-together found newspaper painted different colors according to the day of collection. The work's hefty Conceptual framework, incessant track-keeping and color coding relates to the work of Danica Phelps and Michael Banicki. The totality suggests an abandoned and terraced work site, or the fragment of a crudely enlarged topographical map. Adding to the sense of irrational industriousness is the fact that everything used to transport and install the piece has stayed in it. 
 Best of show, among the artists' projects, is Mika Rottenberg's hilarious video-installation ''Mary's Cherries.'' The viewer sits in a small room whose walls are covered with plaster Dairy-Queen-dip curls (lifesize) and watching, on video, the goings-on in a stack of three similar rooms. Each is inhabited by a hefty woman of a certain age wearing a bright uniform suggestive of a fast-food worker or a washroom attendant, who sits pedaling on an exercise bike while performing tasks and passing things to the other women through holes in the floors.
 Red fingernails are clipped, pounded into pulp, and passed along, only to regrow. Maraschino cherries are -- pardon the expression -- popped, then pounded and passed on. Hamburgers and damp washcloths arrive by conveyor belt and are distributed. As everything whirs along, each transaction is signaled by a call-out from one woman to the others above or below: Mary, Barbara, Rose. The sound is as good as the color. A strange mixture of sexual rite, beauty treatment and assembly-line labor is implied. If Matthew Barney's film epic doesn't come to mind -- in particular the languid sylphlike flight attendants of ''Cremaster 1'' -- you may be living in a different universe than I am. 
 Finally, don't miss Michael Lin's ''Grind'' in P.S. 1's refurbished cafe: an expanse of hot pink faux linoleum with a huge floral pattern that evokes both chintz and the peony motif of Chinese art. Swooping down from the ceiling to cover the entire floor, it suggests a giant roll of fabric unfurled for our perusal. I hate to say it, because I'm a fan of his work, but it is better than the Rudolf Stingel's piece at Grand Central Terminal. 
 If art is your main interest, it might not be a good idea to visit P.S. 1 on a Saturday afternoon. The music booms off the courtyard walls and the hallways and galleries can fill up with people. Still, it is gratifying to realize that some of them came to dance and then stayed to look around, and that the contemporary arts audience is expanding before your eyes.

''Hard Light'' and ''Curious Crystals of Unusual Purity'' are on view at P.S. 1 Contemporary Art Center, 22-25 Jackson Avenue at 46th Avenue, Long Island City, Queens, through Sept. 27. ''Lee Lozano: Drawn From Life, 1961-1971'' and the nARCHITECTS ''Canopy'' end Sept. 5. Smaller shows will close at different times in September: (718) 784-2084,

HEADLINE: Oil Prices and Some Weak Profits Weigh Down Shares

BYLINE: By Bloomberg News

 BODY:
Stocks dropped yesterday amid disappointing news from companies like PepsiCo, Pfizer and Nokia, and as oil prices settled near six-week highs.
 The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index fell 4.78 points, or 0.4 percent, to 1,106.69. The Dow Jones industrial average dropped 45.64 points, or 0.5 percent, to 10,163.16, the lowest level since May 26. The Nasdaq composite index fell 2.17, or 0.1 percent, to 1,912.71, for its fourth straight loss, the longest streak since April 30. 
 ''It's an unforgiving climate right now,'' said Cummins Catherwood, who helps manage $750 million at Walnut Asset Management in Philadelphia. ''When you have a success, they yawn and give you a little pat on the back. When you have less than a success, they bang you on the head.''
 Seven stocks advanced for every five that fell on the New York Stock Exchange. Some 1.41 billion shares changed hands on the Big Board, in line with the three-month daily average.
 Even as companies have begun to report second-quarter earnings, the fluctuations in the stock market have been muted.
 In the last month, the S.&P. 500 has risen or fallen more than 1 percent during the day only twice, on July 1 and July 6.
 ''The earnings haven't been phenomenal,'' said Todd Leone, head of listed trading at SG Cowen & Company. ''There is no volatility. There is nothing to get the market moving in one way or the other.''
 Oil prices held near their highest since June 1. Crude for August delivery lost 0.5 percent, to $40.77 a barrel in New York. On Wednesday, oil prices increased 4.1 percent, raising concern that higher fuel costs will curb spending by consumers and companies.
 PepsiCo shares lost $1.49, to $51.92, the lowest price since March 26. The company had second-quarter profit of 61 cents a share, matching the average analyst estimate in a Thomson First Call poll, as sales rose at the slowest pace in a year. Earnings for the year should be at least $2.29, the company said. Analysts had expected profit of $2.31, according to Thomson.
 Pfizer, the world's biggest drug maker, declined $1.43, to $32.58. The 4.2 percent drop was the biggest in the Dow average. The company reduced its full-year sales forecast by about $1 billion, to $53 billion, because of lower revenue for some products and also because of foreign-currency fluctuations. The company said it would give details when it reports earnings on Wednesday.
 Nokia, the Finnish company that is the world's largest maker of mobile phones, said third-quarter profit and sales would fall as it cuts prices to counter increased competition. Its shares lost $1.79, or 13 percent, to $12.45 on the Big Board. The shares were among the five most active in the United States, with 61 million shares traded.
 Apple Computer climbed $3.35, or 11 percent, to $32.93, for the biggest gain in the S.&P. 500. The company said fiscal third-quarter earnings more than tripled on a threefold climb in iPod shipments. Excluding some costs, profit was 17 cents a share, more than the average analyst estimate of 15 cents in a Thomson survey.
 SanDisk gained $4.11, or 21 percent, to $24.09. The company, the biggest maker of memory cards used in digital cameras, says sales this quarter may exceed analysts' estimates. Second-quarter profit rose 71 percent and the earnings per share, at 38 cents, exceeded the estimate of 30 cents in a Thomson poll.
 Treasury prices changed little yesterday; the benchmark 10-year note was unchanged.

HEADLINE: Labor Board Says Graduate Students at Private Universities Have No Right to Unionize

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE and KAREN W. ARENSON

 BODY:
The fast-growing movement to unionize graduate students at the nation's private universities suffered a crushing setback yesterday when the National Labor Relations Board reversed itself and ruled that students who worked as research and teaching assistants did not have the right to unionize.
 In a case involving Brown University, the labor board ruled 3 to 2 that graduate teaching and research assistants were essentially students, not workers, and thus should not have the right to unionize to negotiate over wages, benefits and other conditions of employment. 
 The Republican-controlled board reversed a four-year-old decision involving New York University, a private institution, in which the board, then controlled by Democrats, concluded that graduate teaching and research assistants should be able to unionize because their increased responsibilities had essentially turned them into workers. 
 As a result of the 2000 N.Y.U. ruling, students there formed the first graduate employees' union at a private university in the nation. (Graduate student workers at public universities are governed by state labor laws rather than federal law, and many states have given them the right to unionize.) 
 Sheldon E. Steinbach, vice president and general counsel for the American Council on Education, a trade group that represents universities and other educational institutions, called the ruling ''magnificent'' but said he was not surprised by it because of the labor board's changed lineup. The N.Y.U. decision was itself a reversal of the board's decades-old position that graduate assistants should not be able to unionize.
 ''The previous decision in the N.Y.U. case overturned over 30 years of determinations by the National Labor Relations Board on whether graduate students who worked as teaching and research assistants were students or employees,'' Mr. Steinbach said. ''And it threatened the traditional relationship between colleges and their graduate student assistants.'' 
 But Edward J. McElroy, the secretary-treasurer of the American Federation of Teachers, who is set to be elected the union's president today, called the decision ''outrageous.''
 ''These people obviously are workers,'' Mr. McElroy said. ''If members of the N.L.R.B. can't recognize a worker when they see one, they shouldn't be on a national labor board.'' 
 After the N.Y.U. decision, graduate teaching and research assistants at Brown, Columbia, Tufts and the University of Pennsylvania voted on whether they should unionize, but those universities appealed to the National Labor Relations Board. The votes were not counted while the cases were pending.
 One of the board's five seats was vacant until last December, so it was effectively split and it postponed ruling on many issues, including this one. That left the unionization efforts in limbo. 
 Lauren Nauta, a graduate teaching assistant in history at the University of Pennsylvania, said many of her colleagues were fuming about the ruling. ''We think it's an injustice that graduate employees at private universities have been denied the same right as those at public universities,'' she said. ''This ruling shows the partisan nature of the N.L.R.B.''
 It is unclear what yesterday's ruling will mean for the future of the graduate employees' union at N.Y.U., which now has a contract with the university. Once the current contract expires, labor experts said, the school may no longer be required to recognize the union or bargain with it. 
 N.Y.U. officials said yesterday that they were ''gratified'' by the labor board's decision, but declined to say whether they would continue to live with their graduate student union or end the relationship when the union contract expires next year.
 The contract that N.Y.U. reached with the union representing its graduate student assistants in 2002 raised stipends for many of them by nearly 40 percent, provided health care benefits and paid them extra if they worked more than 20 hours a week. 
 In its decision, the labor board rejected a petition by the United Automobile Workers to represent 450 graduate students at Brown who served as teaching and research assistants.
 The board noted that graduate students spend most of their energy and hours on their studies, rather than their work. Stating that the National Labor Relations Act was ''designed to cover economic relationships,'' the majority concluded: ''The Board's longstanding rule that it will not assert jurisdiction over relationships that are 'primarily educational' is consistent with these principles.'' 
 In conclusion, the board stated that ''there is a significant risk, even a strong likelihood, that the collective-bargaining process will be detrimental to the educational process.''
 Philip Wheeler, the U.A.W.'s director for New York and New England, derided the labor board's logic.
 ''I understand that they say it would be too disruptive to the great American education system,'' Mr. Wheeler said. ''Once upon a time, they said that unionizing would be too disruptive for American manufacturing. They were wrong then, and they are wrong now.''

HEADLINE: Metro Briefing New York: Albany: Joblessness Up In New York City

BYLINE: By Lydia Polgreen (NYT); Compiled by George James

 BODY:
New York City's unemployment rate rose in June by 0.8 percent, to 7.8 percent from 7 percent in May, even as the city experienced relatively strong job growth, according to data released yesterday by the State Department of Labor. 
The city added 3,500 jobs in June, according to the city comptroller, William C. Thompson Jr., who said the rise in the unemployment rate may reflect a surge of people returning to the job market. The private sector grew by 6,100 jobs, but government employment fell by 2,600 jobs. The rest of the state is keeping pace with the nation in job growth, the numbers show, while the city is still lagging slightly. Lydia Polgreen (NYT)

HEADLINE: Deal in Mexico Makes 4 Banks Absorb Losses From Loans

BYLINE: By ELISABETH MALKIN

DATELINE: MEXICO CITY, July 15 

 BODY:
Four banks, including the local units of Citigroup and HSBC, have agreed to absorb some losses stemming from the banking crisis of the mid-1990's, ending a dispute with regulators, legislators said Thursday.
 Under the agreement, the banks will absorb about $826 million in bad loans and allow a limited audit of some $600 million in questionable loans, said Senator Fauzi Hamdan and Congressman Manuel Perez Cardenas, both from the ruling National Action Party. 
 In addition, the banks have agreed to open sealed working papers from a 1998 audit. Legislators believe that those papers may reveal additional questionable loans. 
 Press reports estimated that the total loss for the banks could reach $1.5 billion, once loss-sharing provisions and any illegal loans uncovered by the audits are taken into account. The $700 million in bad credits that the banks have agreed to absorb are insider loans, money that the banks lent to board members or to companies controlled by friends. 
 Legislators and the government agency that inherited the bad loans have been pressing the banks to allow an audit. But the banks have resisted and tied up the issue in court. 
 ''Finally, a reasonable, fair and legal attitude prevailed'' among the banks, Mr. Hamdan said. ''It's a fair solution.''
 The four banks involved are Citigroup's Banamex unit; HSBC; Banco Bilbao Vizcaya Argentaria's Mexican bank known as BBVA-Bancomer; and a Mexican bank, Banorte. At the time of the banking crisis, all the banks were owned by Mexicans. 
 The four banks sold some $6 billion in bad loans under the bailout plan, an amount that has swelled to about $20 billion with interest. Most of the cost of the bailout was a result of bank failures, and the four banks involved in the auditing dispute have long argued that they were unfairly singled out given that they were among the few left standing.
 Analysts said that while the amount involved was not significant to the banks, the agreement eliminated a source of risk to the banking system. 
 ''We view the agreement as positive for the financial system as a whole,'' wrote Jason Mollin, a Latin America banking analyst for Bear Stearns in New York, in a report Thursday. 
 Gustavo Lopez, senior director for Latin America financial institutions at Fitch Ratings in New York, said, ''The agreement would be beneficial because it would avoid a further escalation of this issue.''
 The agreement ends a politically charged element of the government's $100 billion rescue of Mexico's banks after the peso devaluation in December 1994. As interest rates soared to 100 percent, debtors simply stopped paying their loans, leaving the banks with billions of dollars of bad loans. To capitalize the banks, the government stepped in, buying the bad loans in return for bonds.
 But the bonds, called Fobaproa bonds after the executive agency that issued them, were never backed by Congress, which has had to authorize interest payments with each year's budget. 
 Legislators, along with the government regulator that inherited the bad loans, have been pressing for an audit. The regulator, called the Institute for the Protection of Bank Savings, has held up the exchange of Fobaproa bonds for new bonds that would not require approval from Congress every year.
 Since almost $17 billion of the Fobaproa notes fall due in 2005, the exchange was becoming urgent for the banks, given the possibility that legislators might decide not to approve some or all of the payments.
 The deal unblocks the bond exchange. Instead, interest payments and amortizations on the new bonds will not need yearly congressional approval.

HEADLINE: Renewed State Efforts Made Against Same-Sex Marriage

BYLINE: By JAMES DAO

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 15 

 BODY:
The defeat of a federal constitutional amendment to prohibit same-sex marriage is spurring conservative groups to redouble efforts in a dozen states where similar amendments to state constitutions are likely to be on the ballot this year, proponents of the measures say.
 Partisans on both sides have already begun organizing campaigns in many of those states, raising money, preparing advertising scripts and mobilizing get-out-the-vote operations that could increase turnout in several presidential swing states.
 Many political analysts say President Bush is almost certain to benefit from the mobilization of conservatives in those states, particularly in Michigan and Oregon, where amendments seem likely to make the ballot.
 ''It will generate higher turnout among conservative Christians, who would tend to vote for President Bush,'' said John Green, director of the Ray C. Bliss Institute for Applied Politics at Akron University. 
 ''If the election stays close -- and, boy, it looks really close in Ohio -- then if turnout is increased by three or four points because of this issue, that could make the difference,'' Mr. Green said.
 Supporters of a ban are still collecting signatures in Ohio, but people on both sides expect the measure to appear on the state's ballot. 
 Democrats contend that most voters are more concerned about the economy and Iraq than same-sex marriage. Mr. Bush's support for constitutional amendments banning same-sex marriage could also hurt him among moderate swing voters, many Democrats say.
 Many polls show that a large majority of Americans would support an amendment that would allow marriage only between a man and a woman. But a New York Times/CBS News poll in March also found that 56 percent of voters believed that the issue was not important enough to justify changing the Constitution.
 Poll results can vary depending on how questions are asked. Some polls show that support for amendments declines when respondents are told the measures explicitly prohibit marriage between same-sex partners, the Pew Research Center says. 
 Mr. Bush endorsed the federal amendment, saying a traditional definition of marriage should be enshrined in the Constitution to defend against ''activist courts.'' The Senate defeated the amendment on Wednesday. A White House spokesman said the president would also support efforts to amend state constitutions.
 Senator John Kerry, the presumptive Democratic nominee, has said he supports defining marriage as the union of a man and a woman, but does not think a constitutional amendment is needed. His office did not return calls on Thursday seeking his position on state amendments.
 Legislatures in seven states have already approved amendments that will be put before voters this year, starting with Missouri on Aug. 3 and Louisiana on Sept. 18, according to the Human Rights Campaign, a gay rights group. Georgia, Kentucky, Mississippi, Oklahoma and Utah will follow in November. 
 Supporters of amendments have also collected enough signatures in Arkansas, Michigan, Montana and Oregon to place proposed amendments on ballots this fall. Those signatures are being reviewed, but experts believe most, and probably all, will succeed. 
 In Ohio and North Dakota, signatures are still being collected. Organizers in both states say they are confident they will gather more than enough signatures to get on the ballot in November, an assessment opponents do not dispute. 
 Amendment supporters said that although the federal amendment was soundly defeated in the Senate on Wednesday, the setback would energize conservatives to go to the polls for state amendments. 
 ''As long as Washington is not doing anything to prevent the trend line that is in place now, it will spur more state efforts,'' said Gary Bauer, chairman of the Campaign for Working Families, a political action committee that supports the efforts. 
 But opponents of the amendments said that the arguments used to defeat the federal amendment would also prevail in the states. ''We don't want to look back years from now on something we placed in our Constitution that we come to regret,'' said Rebekah Kassell, spokeswoman for Equality In Oregon, a group fighting the amendment. ''It should remain a timeless and sacred document.''
 In Ohio, an array of religious and conservative groups have sent petitions to more than 100,000 households with notes urging them to gather signatures, said Phil Burress, president of Citizens for Community Values, a group based in Cincinnati that is spearheading the drive. 
 The groups include Focus on the Family, the Family Research Council, the American Family Association and several conservative Christian churches, he said. The groups plan to gather more than 500,000 signatures, though only 323,000 are required, he said.
 Opponents of the Ohio amendment said they hoped to recruit support from Ohio businesses, saying that the measure would discourage highly qualified gay and lesbian employees from coming to Ohio.
 Alan Melamed, campaign manager for Ohioans Protecting Our Constitution, which is fighting the amendment, said it included broad language that could make domestic partner benefits for opposite-sex couples unconstitutional. Many major corporations and several colleges in Ohio offer such benefits to their employees.
 But proponents of the Ohio amendment said it would not prohibit private companies from offering domestic-partner benefits. 
 Missouri, which will vote on its constitutional amendment during an Aug. 3 primary, is being watched as a bellwether for how other states may vote. The Legislature approved the amendment with overwhelming support. But opponents contend that many voters remain open to arguments that it is discriminatory.

HEADLINE: Former Leader Is Still a Power In China's Life

BYLINE: By JOSEPH KAHN

DATELINE: BEIJING, July 14 

 BODY:
With bold front-page headlines and top billing on the main television news show, China's state media announced this week that Jiang Zemin, the country's military chief, had visited the northern city of Shenyang and called on troops there ''to master revolutionary theory.''
 At first glance, the item seemed like just another dutiful recounting of the prosaic meetings and utterances of senior leaders, standard fare for the Communist Party-controlled media. But this report was notable for one fact: Mr. Jiang's visit took place in January 1991.
 The reports shed no light on why the authorities had trumpeted a seemingly unexceptional event 13 years after it happened. But editors and experts say Mr. Jiang, 77, may consider himself as having entered the pantheon of Communist giants, along with Mao Zedong and Deng Xiaoping, entitling him to re-release what he views as his great political moments. 
 More significant, it is the latest indication that Mr. Jiang, who handed the titles of Communist Party chief and president to Hu Jintao in 2002, still holds ultimate power in China and has no immediate plans to give up his remaining position as head of the military. Some members of the party elite had expressed a desire that he do so this fall, when the party convenes its fourth plenum, or national planning session.
 The consequences of Mr. Jiang's prolonged reign are substantial, party officials, editors and political analysts say. Mr. Jiang has retained final say on the most delicate foreign policy issues, as well as some prickly domestic disputes, even though he no longer holds China's top government and party posts. 
 Chinese party officials and Western experts say split leadership has contributed to increased political repression at home and heightened chances of military conflict with Taiwan, while raising the specter of a power struggle down the road.
 ''Divided leadership makes it much harder to pursue compromise positions on sensitive issues, either in domestic or foreign policy,'' said Kenneth Lieberthal, a former Clinton administration China specialist who is now at the University of Michigan. ''Tactically, this makes it more difficult to be either nimble or decisive.''
 Mr. Jiang has stressed the need to accelerate preparations to attack Taiwan in the event the island pursues independence, a stance that may also make him seem indispensable to the military at a crucial juncture, party officials say.
 He recently overruled Mr. Hu's attempts to develop a new framework for China's foreign policy, when he rejected using the phrase ''peaceful rise'' to describe China's emergence as a global power, two people involved in those discussions said. The term had been carefully vetted -- and used repeatedly by Mr. Hu -- before Mr. Jiang voiced his objections.
 It was also Mr. Jiang who decided to detain Jiang Yanyong, the Chinese doctor who earned wide renown for exposing the cover-up of the SARS epidemic last year and calling for a re-evaluation of the 1989 crackdown on democracy protests, people informed about the doctor's detention said. Dr. Jiang, who is not related to Jiang Zemin, has spent nearly 45 days in military custody, where he has been subjected to extended ''study sessions'' to change his political thinking, these people said.
 Mr. Hu and Mr. Jiang have not feuded publicly. Mr. Hu, in fact, has remained studiously deferential, allowing Mr. Jiang to precede him at official events, despite the fact that Mr. Hu nominally outranks him. When both Mr. Hu and Mr. Jiang meet the same visiting dignitary, Mr. Jiang's comments often get more prominent coverage.
 The leadership has tried to persuade people that laws and institutions outweigh any individual. But China's orderly transition to a new leadership in 2002, once promoted by the party as a sign of political maturity, is now viewed as incomplete by many people, including Mr. Jiang. 
 In a meeting with Condoleezza Rice, the national security adviser, at the Zhongnanhai leadership compound last week, Mr. Jiang volunteered that he was ''handing over more and more power'' to Mr. Hu, according to an American official who attended the meeting. The statement implied that ultimate authority still rested with Mr. Jiang, who would dictate the pace of change.
 The continued prominence of Mr. Jiang may partly account for the relatively tight political environment, including a captive press and reduced scope for debating policy issues, political analysts say. Paradoxically, the atmosphere is more stifling than in the final years of his official rule, perhaps partly because Mr. Hu wants to avoid any liberalization that could lead to social unrest -- and expose him to censure -- before he consolidates power, these analysts said.
 Mr. Jiang steered China through a period of rapid economic growth and stable foreign relations during his long tenure. But party officials say he has now associated himself with the hard-line position of some elements in the army that favors taking decisive steps to stop the drift toward independence in Taiwan.
 Chinese hard-liners, both military and civilian, argue that the recent re-election of Chen Shui-bian as president of Taiwan has confirmed fears that Taiwan will sooner or later seek formal independence, which Beijing has promised to oppose militarily. Bush administration officials say China has recently emphasized using force to restrain Taiwan, even though the Americans believe that it is still possible -- and highly preferable -- to reduce cross-strait tensions through dialogue.
 Liu Yazhou, the deputy political commissar of the Chinese Air Force, wrote an essay circulated on Chinese Web sites in May that discussed preparations for conflict with Taiwan and quoted Mr. Jiang as saying, ''We must fight a war with Taiwan.'' 
 While it remains unknown whether Mr. Hu would steer a more conciliatory course if he had unchallenged authority, Mr. Jiang's stance leaves little space for alternative views, analysts say.
 When Mr. Hu has tried to put his own stamp on Chinese foreign policy, Mr. Jiang has prevented him from doing so.
 Mr. Hu's circle of advisers at the Central Party School, the Communist Party university that Mr. Hu managed before he was elevated to the top rank, spent months preparing a vision statement for China's emergence as a regional and world power.
 They coined the term ''peaceful rise,'' which they said reflected a consensus view that China could break historical precedents and become a great power without using military force to exert influence.
 The idea became a staple of academic conferences and scholarly books. Mr. Hu and Wen Jiabao, the prime minister, both used the phrase repeatedly.
 But in March, around the time of the Taiwan election, pressure from Mr. Jiang and the military prompted Mr. Hu to stop using the term, two people involved in the discussions said. Some scholars have continued to refer to the peaceful rise theory in their studies. 
 Chinese foreign policy experts said the debate signaled the delicacy of proscribing military force as a foreign policy tool while Mr. Jiang stressed the threat of Taiwan independence. But they said it also reflected Mr. Jiang's desire to prevent Mr. Hu from formulating a new doctrine, even if the contents were not especially contentious.
 The way dissent by Dr. Jiang, the SARS whistle-blower, was handled by the leadership has also tended to underline assertions that Mr. Jiang remains the top decision maker, people directly informed about the doctor's case said.
 Dr. Jiang wrote a letter in February that challenged the leadership to apologize for violently suppressing protests around Beijing 15 years ago. As a senior Communist Party official, elite surgeon and a military officer who is thought to have a rank equivalent to lieutenant general or major general in the West, Dr. Jiang's plea was treated as a political crisis.
 The ruling Politburo, over which Mr. Hu presides, discussed Dr. Jiang's case shortly after his letter circulated and took steps to make sure that the doctor did not repeat his public appeal. But it was Mr. Jiang, acting in his capacity as chairman of the Central Military Commission, who decided to detain Dr. Jiang on June 1 and subject him to political indoctrination, according to the people informed about the case.
 It is unclear when Dr. Jiang will be released or whether he will be charged with a crime, though the latter action seems unlikely. Some party officials say they regard the detention of Dr. Jiang, considered a hero by many Chinese, as a mistake.
 ''Jiang created this problem,'' one person connected to the case said, referring to the military chief. ''Jiang will have to find a way out.''

HEADLINE: Philippines Viewed as Being Forced to Yield on Hostage

BYLINE: By CARLOS H. CONDE

DATELINE: MANILA, July 15 

 BODY:
President Gloria Macapagal-Arroyo had no choice but to accede to the demands of Iraqi insurgents who abducted a Philippine truck driver last week and threatened to kill him unless the country withdrew its troops by July 20, analysts and critics said Thursday.
 The risk of disappointing Washington, her most important ally, was easily outweighed by the potential political retaliation that could have imperiled Mrs. Arroyo's political and economic agenda for the next six years, they said. 
 The hostage, Angelo dela Cruz, 46, a father of eight, appeared Thursday night on Al Jazeera, the satellite network, looking and sounding upbeat. Al Jazeera quoted him as saying that he would return home soon, although the militants supposedly told the network that Mr. dela Cruz would not be released until the last Filipino soldier was out. Mr. dela Cruz thanked the Philippine government for agreeing to the withdrawal, which started Wednesday with the departure of 8 of the 51 Filipino police officers and soldiers in Iraq.
 But Mrs. Arroyo's decision ''was very serious and damaging'' to Manila's relationship with Washington, a United States diplomat stationed here said. He did not elaborate, except to add that Washington had not expected such a move from Mrs. Arroyo, who is widely considered its strongest supporter in Southeast Asia and whose country has received by far the most military aid of any country in the region.
 The United States ambassador to Manila, Francis Ricciardone, said Wednesday that America continued to support the Philippines. ''We are allies,'' he told reporters. ''We are here for you.'' 
 But Edgardo E. Dagdag, a national security expert at the Asian Center of the University of the Philippines, said the pullout ''will raise a lot of questions as to how dependable the Philippines is as an ally in the fight against terrorism.'' The Philippines, he said, needs the United States in its own fight against terrorism. ''So if we are vacillating now, I doubt if we can get America's full support,'' Mr. Dagdag said.
 But Mrs. Arroyo's options were limited, said Teodoro Casino, a congressman who is also a leader of the country's largest leftist group, the New Patriotic Alliance. ''The only logical explanation for this change in policy and her willingness to risk disappointing her allies is to tame the protests,'' he said.
 Moreover, Mr. Casino said, there are lingering suspicions of fraud in the vote for president in May. ''Mrs. Arroyo still has not convinced a significant section of the population that she won fair and square in the last election. She does not need this kind of controversy so early in her term.''
 He said she wanted to institute changes -- among them higher taxes, cuts in government spending and increases in electricity, fuel and transportation costs -- that were sure to prove unpopular. 
 The crisis could also alienate the millions of overseas Filipino workers whose dollar remittances had been propping up the economy for decades but who contended that the government had not done enough to protect them, said Maita Santiago, secretary-general of Migrante, a group of Filipino migrant workers.''She seems to think that it would be far easier to explain to the U.S. her action on the hostage situation than to appease an angry public in case Angelo dela Cruz dies,'' Mr. Casino said. ''If Mr. dela Cruz is released, she will definitely make it up to the U.S.''

HEADLINE: Bush's Not-So-Big Tent

BYLINE: By BOB HERBERT. 
E-mail: bobherb@nytimes.com

 BODY:
Just as George W. Bush is on track to be the first president since Herbert Hoover to preside over a net loss of jobs, he is now the first president since Hoover to fail to meet with the N.A.A.C.P. during his entire term in office.
 Mr. Bush and the leadership of the nation's oldest and largest civil rights organization get along about as well as the Hatfields and the McCoys. The president was invited to the group's convention in Philadelphia this week, but he declined. 
 That Mr. Bush thumbed his nose at N.A.A.C.P. officials is not the significant part of this story. The Julian Bonds and Kweisi Mfumes of the world can take care of themselves at least as well as Mr. Bush in the legalized gang fight called politics.
 What is troubling is Mr. Bush's relationship with black Americans in general. He's very good at using blacks as political props. And the props are too often part of an exceedingly cynical production.
 Four years ago, on the first night of the Republican convention, a parade of blacks was hauled before the television cameras (and the nearly all-white audience in the convention hall) to sing, to dance, to preach and to praise a party that has been relentlessly hostile to the interests of blacks for half a century.
 I wrote at the time that ''you couldn't tell whether you were at the Republican National Convention or the Motown Review.''
 That exercise in modern-day minstrelsy was supposed to show that Mr. Bush was a new kind of Republican, a big-tent guy who would welcome a more diverse crowd into the G.O.P. That was fiction. It wasn't long before black voters would find themselves mugged in Florida, and soon after that Mr. Bush was steering the presidency into a hard-right turn.
 Among the most important props of that 2000 campaign were black children. Mr. Bush could be seen hugging them at endless photo-ops. He said a Bush administration would do great things for them. He promised to transform public education in America. He hijacked the trademarked slogan of the Children's Defense Fund, ''Leave No Child Behind,'' and refashioned it for his own purposes. He pasted the new version, ''No Child Left Behind,'' onto one of the signature initiatives of his presidency, a supposedly historic education reform act.
 The only problem is that, to date, the act has been underfunded by $26 billion. A lot of those kids the president hugged have been left behind.
 And why not? They can't do much for him. Michael Moore's ''Fahrenheit 9/11'' captured a telling presidential witticism. Mr. Bush, appearing before a well-heeled gathering in New York, says: ''This is an impressive crowd: the haves, and the have-mores. Some people call you the elite. I call you my base.''
 It wasn't really his base. But the comment spoke volumes.
 Mr. Bush said he was a different kind of Republican, but what black voters see are tax cuts for the very wealthy and underfunded public schools. What they see is an economy that sizzles for the haves and the have-mores, but a harrowing employment crisis for struggling blacks, especially black men. (When the Community Service Society looked at the proportion of the working-age population with jobs in New York City it found that nearly half of all black men between the ages of 16 and 64 were not working last year. That's a Depression-era statistic.)
 In Florida, where the president's brother is governor, and Texas, where the president once was the governor, state officials have been pulling the plug on health coverage for low-income children. The president could use his considerable clout to put a stop to that sort of thing, but he hasn't.
 And now we know that Florida was gearing up for a reprise of the election shenanigans of 2000. It took a court order to get the state to release a list of 48,000 suspected felons that was to be used to purge people from the voting rolls. It turned out that the list contained thousands of names of black people, who tend to vote Democratic, and hardly any names of Hispanics, who in Florida tend to vote Republican.
 Once their ''mistake'' was caught, the officials scrapped the list.
 Mr. Bush plans to address the Urban League convention in Detroit next week. That would be an excellent time for him to explain to an understandably skeptical audience why he campaigned one way -- as a big-tent compassionate conservative -- and governed another.

HEADLINE: Around the World, Markets Are the Dullest in Years. Is That Good News?

BYLINE: By FLOYD NORRIS

 BODY:
MAY you live in boring times. For those familiar with the old Chinese curse about living in interesting times, boring may sound like a blessing, and it may well become one for investors. But it is flustering money managers this year. 
 It is not that they are losing money, although some are. It is just that few seem to be making much money. It has been more than a decade since stock markets have traded in such a narrow range for the first half of a year. 
 One hedge fund manager complains that nothing is working this year -- for him or his competitors. It is a bit like what they say about New England weather: if you don't like the trend, wait five minutes and it will change.
 The Standard & Poor's 500 has gone nowhere. It is down about half a percent since the end of 2003, with the year's high, of 1,163.23 on March 5, only 8.1 percent higher than the low of 1,076.32, reached May 12. The range is the smallest for the start of a year since 1993. 
 And the United States is far from alone. In France, the first six months saw a range of 9.6 percent in the CAC 40, the smallest swing since that index was reconstituted in 1987. In Germany, the year got off to the most boring start since 1990 for the DAX index, with a range of 13.1 percent. In Britain, the FTSE All Shares index has shown a range of 6.5 percent, the smallest since 1982.
 In Japan, long the leader in stock market volatility, the Nikkei 225 is up 6.9 percent this year, the best of any major market. The range of 18.4 percent is larger than in other markets but is Japan's smallest since 1996.
 Perhaps dull markets are correlated with discontent with politicians. The economic news has generally been good around the world, but this has not been a year of joy for political parties in power. The Spanish government was voted out of office. The European parliament elections saw the governing parties rebuffed in nearly every country. In Japan, the upper house elections were a setback for the ruling party. The approval ratings for President Bush have declined. 
 Dull markets could reflect an uncertainty over the state of the world that has frustrated investors and voters.
 Going back to 1928, when the S.&P. 500 began, only two previous presidential election years produced an index that had as listless a first six months as in 2004, and in each case the news was bad for the incumbent party. In 1952, the range was 8.1 percent, and the Democrats were swept out of office. In 1992, the range was 7.3 percent, and President Bush failed to win re-election.
 The probable explanation this year is that the good economic news was foreseen by the markets, leading to the market gains that began in the fall of 2002 and petered out this year. Higher interest rates, or fear of them, often act as a sedative on markets, causing them to slow down until more evidence appears to show how high the rates will go and what economic effect they will have. Investors may be waiting for that evidence, as they did in 1994. The end of rising rates that year was followed by a very good 1995.
 In most cases, the doubts shown by dull markets have been resolved with good news. Markets in the United States, France, Germany and Britain have been more likely to show good gains after boring first halves than after exciting beginnings to the year. (In Japan, where bad economic news has been the rule rather than the exception for the last 14 years, the opposite pattern has prevailed.)
 Since 1971 in the United States, there have been 14 years before this one when the S.&P. range was under 15 percent. Prices rose in the second half of 12 of those years, for an average gain of 5.6 percent. But if the early range was greater, the market was more likely to go down than up. The average move was a gain of just 0.4 percent.
 Boring, it appears, can be a harbinger of good times.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Boston Scientific Widens Recall of Some of Its Stents
Shares of Boston Scientific plunged nearly 8 percent after the company said that it was voluntarily widening the recall of two of the devices it makes to treat heart disease. The recall involves about 85,000 of the drug-coated devices that the company introduced earlier this year and another 11,000 of the devices it made without the special drug coating.
 While Boston Scientific is not recalling all of the devices, called stents, it said that it decided to recall some of them because of a problem that can occur when a doctor first inserts the device into a patient. The recall comes after reports of three deaths and 43 injuries, the company said. [Page C2.]

Growth in China Is Slowing
China's economy grew at a weaker-than-expected 9.6 percent pace in the second quarter, suggesting that Beijing may be achieving a soft landing for the economy. [C2.]

A Modest Rise in Consumer Prices
The Consumer Price Index rose 0.3 percent in June -- half the 0.6 percent jump posted for May, but slightly ahead of forecasts by economists for a rise of 0.2 percent. The core index, which excludes food and energy costs, edged up a smaller-than-expected 0.1 percent. [C4.]

Freescale Offers 121 Million Shares
Shares of Freescale Semiconductor, a spinoff of Motorola, closed at $14.02. The initial public offering of 121.6 million shares that raised nearly $1.6 billion was priced at $13 a share, the low end of its estimated range. [C14.]

Halliburton Plan Approved
DII Industries and Kellogg Brown & Root, units of Halliburton that sought bankruptcy protection in December, won court approval for a restructuring plan that includes a $4.2 billion settlement of asbestos claims. [C4.]

Profits Fall 25% at Electrolux
Electrolux posted a 25 percent decline in second-quarter profit largely because of rising steel prices and a decline in sales of floor-care products in the United States. [C2.]

Technology Stocks Decline
Technology and small-cap stocks fell as investors were concerned about a possible slump in profits in the second half of the year. The Nasdaq composite index fell 29.56 points, to 1,883.15. The Nasdaq dipped 3.3 percent for the week, and is down 6 percent so far in 2004. The Dow Jones industrial average dropped 23.38 points, to 10,139.78, and declined 0.7 percent for the week. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index decreased 5.30 points, to 1,101.39, and declined 1 percent for the week. [C4.]

Profits Increase at KeyCorp
KeyCorp reported a 6 percent increase in second-quarter earnings, which it attributed to a gain in commercial loan business and in interest from investment banking services. [C4.]

Delphi Issues an Earnings Warning
The automotive parts supplier Delphi warned that it would report a net loss in the third quarter because of production cuts by Detroit automakers. [C14.]

Judge Approves Boeing Settlement
Judge Marsha J. Pechman of United States District Court in Seattle gave preliminary approval to a settlement in a class-action lawsuit brought against Boeing by women employees contending they were mistreated based on their gender. [C4.]

Bayer to Spin Off Chemicals Unit
Bayer said that it planned to spin off its chemicals division, Lanxess, to shareholders rather than hold an initial public offering. The sale of Lanxess, which makes industrial chemicals and polymers, will allow Bayer to focus on pharmaceuticals and consumer health products. [C2.]

HEADLINE: Faltering Art Fair Chills Chicago

BYLINE: By DAVID BERNSTEIN

DATELINE: CHICAGO, July 16 

 BODY:
The Chicago art establishment, from museums to galleries to artists, still seems shaken by what it perceived to be the failure this spring of its internationally known contemporary art fair.
 Critics thought it the weakest in size and in quality of art in its 25-year existence, and this follows a trend in recent years in which more and more of the world's serious collectors, curators and dealers have been skipping the fair, Art Chicago.
 For a city that sometimes refers to itself as a ''museum without walls'' because of its vaunted architectural tradition and the Picassos, Calders, Dubuffets and Oldenburgs arrayed throughout its business district, this has been a blow not only to its economy but also to its ego.
 The focus of the city's hope to recapture the attention of the international art world is the glittering new Millennium Park, a 24-and-a-half-acre arts hamlet on the city's lakefront that opened on Friday. It included three new significant examples of public art: a swirling steel music pavilion by Frank Gehry; a 110-ton jellybean-shaped sculpture by the British artist Anish Kapoor; and a giant, interactive fountain designed by the Spanish artist Jaume Plensa. 
 Since 1980 and throughout most of the 1990's, much of the art world eagerly descended on Chicago every May for its art exposition on the Navy Pier, an American version of the celebrated contemporary art fair in Basel, Switzerland. (This year's three-day event ended on May 10.) But now Art Chicago is less popular than fairs in New York, London, Paris and, more recently, South Beach for the chic Art Basel Miami.
 Robert Landau, president of Landau Fine Art in Montreal, was a regular exhibitor at Art Chicago but dropped out of the exposition after the 2002 show. ''It's a sad story,'' he said. ''We stuck it out for quite a long time. Unfortunately over the years, the fair has dwindled in importance. The exhibitor mix weakened, and the customer base weakened with the absence of the good galleries.'' Mr. Landau said the fair no longer attracted the art-savvy clientele for the $100 million inventory of modern masters paintings that he put on display. 
 ''The last year we were there we had more customers walking in off Navy Pier who really weren't there to see the art show. We had so many people coming in making remarks like, 'Are any of these paintings real?' '' 
 George Adams, a gallery owner on West 57th Street in New York, and an exhibitor at the Chicago fair since its inception, also skipped it the past couple of years. ''I noticed other galleries were dropping out,'' he said. ''The fair was looking a little bit stale. The extras starting disappearing.'' Mr. Adams said Thomas Blackman, the organizer of Art Chicago, had never updated or improved his show, even as more rival fairs emerged onto the scene, particularly, Art Basel Miami Beach, which had its debut in December 2002. 
 ''Tom's got to hear the warning signs,'' Mr. Adams said, referring to the initial buzz about Art Basel Miami. ''This fair is going to blow him out of the water if he's not careful. But he didn't do anything. He didn't change the fair, he didn't up the ante, he didn't strengthen his organization, he didn't tighten it up. So sure enough, Basel Miami opens and suddenly his fair looks really sleepy.'' 
 Mr. Blackman, who has produced Art Chicago since 1993, conceded that the number of show exhibitors and visitors had steadily declined in recent years. By his count, there were 221 dealers and about 27,000 attendees at the 2000 exposition; this year's show drew 158 dealers and fewer than 22,000 people. ''The show has lost some of its muscle, there's no doubt about that,'' Mr. Blackman admitted. But he played down talk of the fair's demise, suggesting that a comeback is imminent.
 Mr. Blackman, who also produces the San Francisco International Art Exhibition, announced plans last month to change next year's Art Chicago from its traditional May date to July 14-18, citing timing conflicts with the spring art auctions in New York. He also said he would no longer hold the show at Navy Pier, but rather move it to a temporary exhibition space, a 125,000-square-foot tent, in downtown Chicago. 
 ''The whole international art calendar has changed so much since we first started in the 80's,'' Mr. Blackman said. ''We used to be sandwiched in between the auctions in New York; now we're smack-dab in the middle of them. July is a time that is much more open. I think it's also a time that will allow us to take advantage of the benefits of being in Chicago. We have some of our larger museum shows that we might be able to tag on to.'')
 The decline of Art Chicago has become a matter of concern to those involved with the visual arts here, many of whom say they feel that the weakened fair may be emblematic of the vibrancy of the city's art scene. 
 ''If you take the art expo as a litmus test, then, yes, there has been some slippage,'' said Ed Paschke, a Chicago artist. ''The expo has always been viewed as a measuring stick for the city.'' 
 Without a robust art fair to bring to Chicago the art world's tastemakers and art buyers, there are fears about commercial viability. 
 ''The art fair has been the engine behind the healthiness of the Chicago gallery scene for 25 years,'' said Thomas McCormick, a Chicago-based art dealer. ''It's a big chunk of money that I come to rely on come May.'' 
 Rhona Hoffman, another Chicago gallery owner, agreed. ''There's a big concern, absolutely,'' she said. ''You've got the Armory in New York, Art Basel in Miami and the Frieze fair in London: three newer art fairs, all very international, all very seductive and all taking a lot of people out of Chicago. It remains a very hard blow.'' 
 ''Everyone is scratching their brains to think of a way to bring it back and to make Chicago great again for that purpose,'' Ms. Hoffman said. 
 Opinions vary sharply on Mr. Blackman's new plans for the fair. Some people in the arts are cautiously optimistic; others feel the changes might be too little, too late.
 ''I hate to say it, but I'm not sure he's the one that can turn it around,'' said Richard Gray, a leading Chicago art dealer for 40 years and the former president of the Art Dealers Association of America. ''After all, he's the one that's been running the fair all the time that it's been deteriorating. It's going to be a very, very tough road.'' 
 A spokesman for the Metropolitan Pier and Exposition Authority, the municipal corporation that manages Navy Pier, said it had already received numerous queries from prospective operators for a new fair on the pier, though he declined to name them. 
 ''There are efforts now to do something about the fair -- to work with Tom, work with somebody else -- to get things back on track,'' Mr. Gray said. 
 Mr. McCormick, the dealer, said: 'We're like the wife at home, and Basel Miami is the new, sexy secretary at the office. The day's going to come when it is no longer the sexy, new thing, either.''

HEADLINE: Report Notes Improved Well-Being of U.S. Youth

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 16 

 BODY:
Children in the United States were less likely in 2002 to commit a violent crime or be a victim of one than in 2001, but more of them were living in poverty, according to the government's broadest measure of children's well-being.
 A report released Friday by the Federal Interagency Forum on Child and Family Statistics painted a mostly upbeat picture of children's lives. The birth rate for teenage mothers, which has declined steadily since 1991, hit a record low in 2002. And the death rate went down for young people. 
 But children were more likely to be overweight than they were before, and child poverty inched up after several years of decline, according to the report, which drew together findings from many federal agencies.
 The reduction in teenage births is one gain that should not be overlooked, said Duane Alexander, director of the National Institute of Child Health and Human Development at the National Institutes of Health.
 Teenagers who give birth are less likely to finish high school than other girls their age, he said. Also, infants born to teenage mothers are more likely to be of low birth weight, increasing their chances of blindness, deafness, mental retardation, mental illness and cerebral palsy.
 Young people were less likely to be victimized in a serious violent crime -- murder, rape, robbery or aggravated assault -- or to commit one. In 2002, those ages 12 to 17 were victims of a violent crime at a rate of 11 per 1,000, down from 15 per 1,000 a year earlier. The rate of youths ages 12 to 17 committing violent crimes was 11 per 1,000 in 2002, compared with 19 per 1,000 in 2001.
 The percentage of overweight children increased, reaching 16 percent from 1999 to 2000, up from 11 percent in the early 1990's and 6 percent in the late 1970's.
 The number of children living in poverty also grew, hitting 11.6 million in 2002, up from 11.2 million a year earlier.

HEADLINE: McGreevey Picks Commerce Chief

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: PRINCETON, N.J., July 16 

 BODY:
Gov. James E. McGreevey chose the director of the New Jersey Lottery as his new commerce secretary on Friday, two days after the previous secretary resigned amid questions about his conduct in office. 
 Virginia Bauer, who headed the lottery for less than a year, succeeds William Watley as leader of the Commerce and Economic Growth Commission, which promotes business in the state.
 ''She will be an advocate and ensure that our administration is responsive to the business community,'' Mr. McGreevey said. 
 The commission had a budget of about $16 million last year and 109 employees. The commerce secretary earned about $137,000 last year.
 Ms. Bauer, who has a background in public relations and finance, was picked to head the lottery after her work as an advocate for the survivors of victims of the 9/11 terror attacks brought her to the governor's attention. Ms. Bauer's husband was killed at the World Trade Center.
 Mr. Watley resigned Wednesday after conflict-of-interest questions were raised over his role in a construction loan for his church in Newark.
 The loan came under scrutiny after state investigators raided the offices of Lesly Devereaux, Mr. Watley's former chief of staff, in a separate inquiry. Ms. Devereaux also served as the commission's senior vice president before resigning earlier this month.
 The State Division of Criminal Justice is investigating Mr. Watley's decision to award a no-bid consulting contract to Ms. Devereaux's sister.

HEADLINE: Moderate Inflation in June May Restrain Rate Increases

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 16 

 BODY:
The pace of consumer price increases moderated in June, the government said on Friday, bolstering financial market hopes that the Federal Reserve will stick with a policy of gradual interest rate increases.
 The Consumer Price Index, the most widely used gauge of inflation, rose 0.3 percent -- half the 0.6 percent jump posted for May, when gasoline prices were soaring, but slightly ahead of forecasts by Wall Street economists for a rise of 0.2 percent.
 The core index, which strips out volatile food and energy costs, edged up a smaller-than-expected 0.1 percent in June after a 0.2 percent May increase. In the last 12 months, core inflation has risen 1.9 percent. Energy costs rose 2.6 percent after an even larger 4.6 percent surge in May. 
 Susan Bies, a Federal Reserve Board governor, speaking to reporters in Chicago, expressed satisfaction at the report and said some recent data showing less vigorous expansion in June was not worrisome. ''We're taking a breather, but the fact is, we're still growing,'' she said.
 In another report, the University of Michigan's consumer sentiment index rose slightly, to 96.0 in July from a final reading of 95.6 for June. Analysts said the modest rise was a comforting indicator that consumers were not growing dispirited as some had speculated might be happening after retail sales weakened in June.
 Energy costs remained decisive. The Labor Department, which calculates the index, said energy accounted for about two-thirds of the rise in the broad index. Gasoline, natural gas, fuel oil and electricity costs all were higher than in May.
 Richard Yamarone, an economist at the Argus Research Corporation in New York, said some of the price pressures were ''cost push,'' from commodities like oil and lumber, rather than harder-to-control ''demand pull'' increases that generally reflect rising wage costs.
 ''What that is saying, and the Fed itself is saying, is that this is transitory, cost-push inflation that is commodity-specific and those types of increases have historically been temporary or short-lived,'' he said. 
 Similarly, Ken Mayland, an economist at ClearView Economics in Pepper Pike, Ohio, said that it seemed that some price increases that were so evident in April and May were already easing.
 ''If we think ahead a little bit, gasoline prices have come down, so we can anticipate a sizable negative in the July headline C.P.I.,'' Mr. Mayland added. ''We're not talking zero inflation here, so there is not a case for the Fed to stand pat and not do anything. But the Fed is going to move in the measured pace of 25-basis-point increases.''

HEADLINE: Chess's Lost Soul, Bobby Fischer, Is Held in Tokyo

BYLINE: By BRUCE WEBER and TODD ZAUN; Bruce Weber reported from Washington for this article and Todd Zaun from Tokyo. Dylan McClain contributed reporting from New York.

 BODY:
After two decades of living in secrecy, semi-isolation and increasingly distressed obscurity, Bobby Fischer, the former world chess champion, was arrested Friday by Japanese immigration authorities in Tokyo and accused of trying to leave the country without a valid passport. 
 An American Embassy official in Tokyo confirmed that Mr. Fischer was detained at Narita Airport. Japanese news reports said Mr. Fischer, 61, probably would be deported to the United States, where he faces charges for violating economic sanctions against the former Yugoslavia by playing an exhibition match there in 1992. But Mr. Fischer's immediate future remains unclear. 
 Richard A. Boucher, the State Department spokesman, said it was not yet determined whether the United States would ask that Mr. Fischer be turned over to the American authorities. He said only that Mr. Fischer, who has expressed virulently anti-American views since the warrant was issued for his arrest on Dec. 15, 1992, had been visited by an American consular officer. 
 ''Questions about extradition or charges would have to be answered by the Department of Justice and the appropriate courts,'' Mr. Boucher said. The Justice Department had no comment, but an official said it was looking at the case to determine its legal options, including possible extradition. The official added that it was too soon to predict how the case might turn out. The detention of Mr. Fischer came the day before another longtime American fugitive -- Charles Jenkins, 64, who is accused of deserting the Army in 1965, when he entered North Korea -- was scheduled to arrive in Japan, and who is also expected to be the subject of an American extradition request. 
 It was unclear why Mr. Fischer was in Japan, though it is possible he was living there. In a radio interview broadcast from Manila in June 2003, he told the host that he was in Japan at the time. And chess publications that have long been obsessed with tracking the movements of the mysterious former champion have reported that Mr. Fischer travels frequently between Tokyo and Manila. 
 The episode is just the latest wrinkle in the strange international saga of Mr. Fischer -- indisputably the greatest American chess player in history and some say the greatest ever in the world -- whose life has spiraled weirdly and precipitously downward since his greatest glory. 
 Born in Chicago but reared in Brooklyn, he first drew attention as an adolescent prodigy, able to hold his own with the strongest American players at the Marshall and Manhattan Chess Clubs in Manhattan. A national champion at 14 and a grandmaster at 15, he became an international celebrity in 1972 when, at the height of the cold war, he unseated the Russian world champion, Boris Spassky, in a match in Reykjavik, Iceland. That, however, was to be the last of Mr. Fischer's triumphs. A petulant, demanding man with a cruel unpredictable streak, by the time he became world champion he was already known for his outlandishly self-aggrandizing behavior. It was part of what made him a legend.
 In ''Searching for Bobby Fischer,'' the 1988 book about the chess world that is partly about Mr. Fischer's status as an icon, the author, Fred Waitzkin, summed up Mr. Fischer's behavior in Reykjavik this way: ''He drove the organizers of the tournament to despair. He argued about the choice of chess table, about his hotel room, about the noise in the auditorium, about the proximity of the audience to the players and about the lighting. He demanded that the organizers lend him a Mercedes with an automatic transmission and arrange for the private use of a swimming pool. He came late to each game and kept threatening to pull out of the match if his demands weren't met.''
 It was a harsh eccentricity that soon grew self-destructive. Mr. Fischer's sanity seemed to frazzle in the limelight, and he sank into a contrary isolation that seems to characterize him to this day.
 After the Spassky match, he refused offers to play chess for titanic sums of money, and he lost his title after three years because he refused to defend it against Anatoly Karpov of the Soviet Union. His time was evidently consumed by lawsuits, one brought against him by Chester Fox, who had held the film rights to the Spassky match, but which became worthless because Mr. Fischer had refused to play before the cameras, which he said he could hear whirring. Mr. Fischer unsuccessfully sued a biographer, Brad Darrach, and the Time-Life Corporation, for invasion of privacy. Another suit, against a student group that he claimed published, without permission, remarks he made about his affiliation with a fringe church, also failed and reportedly left him bankrupt.
 A virulent anti-Semite in spite of his own Jewish ancestry (his mother was a Jew), he has claimed that his belongings were stolen by a Jewish conspiracy from a warehouse in Southern California, where he lived during the 1980's. The federal indictment against him after the match in Yugoslavia seemed to ignite an equally virulent anti-American fire in him. Over the past five years, his occasional rants to radio stations in Iceland and Hungary, as well as the Philippines, have been full of hate against Jews and the United States.
 On Sept. 11, 2001, he told a radio talk-show host in Baguio, the Philippines, that the terrorist attacks on the World Trade Center and the Pentagon were ''wonderful news,'' adding he was wishing for a scenario ''where the country will be taken over by the military, they'll close down all the synagogues, arrest all the Jews and secure hundreds of thousands of Jewish ringleaders.'' 
 Mr. Fischer lived for a time in Pasadena, Calif., and it has been reported that from 1975 to 1992, he lived in cheap rooms around Los Angeles. Over the past decade, however, he is known to have lived in Budapest, and reportedly has also lived in the Philippines and Switzerland. 
 For two decades, Mr. Fischer was a specter that haunted the chess world; its greatest genius had vanished with almost no trace. The few people he kept in touch with were under threat that he would never speak to them again if they discussed him -- which was why it was colossal news in 1992 when he was lured out of hiding for a rematch against Mr. Spassky in Yugoslavia. 
 Just before the match, however, the United Nations imposed sanctions against Yugoslavia for supporting Serbian aggression in Bosnia and Herzegovina and the United States banned its citizens from doing business there. Mr. Fischer ignored a formal warning from the government against playing the match, and at a news conference spat on the letter. He won the match, collecting $3.3 million, and has been in exile from the United States ever since.
