HEADLINE: Long-Running Drama At the Loew's Jersey

BYLINE: By CARLY BERWICK

 BODY:
THE Loew's Jersey theater in Jersey City has seen more than its share of uncertainty. There were all the years when it was shut and threatened with demolition. Most recently, the nonprofit group that runs it has been without a legal right to be in the building for more than a year.
 But the days of limbo may soon be over. Jersey City's acting mayor, L. Harvey Smith, wants to give the group, Friends of the Loew's, a five-year lease on the building. Both the mayor's office and Friends of the Loew's say they think the final lease will be signed by the end of summer, as they smooth out issues like the term of renewal and financial commitments. But the City Council still has to agree that changes can be made to a draft lease that was previously approved. 
 ''All of the salient points have been agreed on,'' said Hope Blackburn, the city's corporate council. 
 Pattie Giordan, president of Friends of the Loew's, said: ''The biggest thing is that the city and FOL are now working together to put the deal together. The city's accommodating mood, she said, is different from what it was a few months ago
 Friends of the Loew's has been renovating and running the movie palace, built during Hollywood's golden age, since the early 1990's. But it has been without a right to the building since June 2003. In April, the Smith-led City Council voted to grant a five-year lease; but Mr. Smith, the Council president, became interim mayor when Mayor Glenn D. Cunningham died of a heart attack in late May. Mr. Cunningham had opposed ratifying the lease, saying that it was illegal and that a bigger organization would be better able to make the theater financially self-reliant. He was still negotiating with Friends of the Loew's when he died. 
 Meanwhile, scheduling and fund-raising for the theater have stalled. ''You can't do long-range planning without knowing your position,'' Ms. Giordan said. Performances and events are booked weekend by weekend and still draw crowds. The 1963 movie ''Jason and the Argonauts'' attracted some 600 fans of vintage movies one May weekend. And a February concert by the punk-folk troubadour Conor Oberst sold out all 1,500 seats. 
 For years, though, no one paid attention to the Loew's Jersey. 
 Built in 1929 for the then-stunning sum of $2 million, the theater, boasting a marble entryway, played host to stars like Duke Ellington and Bing Crosby. It was the centerpiece of a once-bustling Journal Square, remembered for its theaters and shopping. 
 For many years the Loew's Jersey languished, as multiplexes were built in the late 1970's by Loews and other theater chains. Finally, in August 1986, the theater closed. The developer that bought it intended to tear it down and put office buildings on the property.
 ''Then it became a Jimmy Stewart movie,'' said Colin Egan, the theater's director. Local preservationists collected 10,000 signatures and 200 people to attend City Council meetings. Demolition was delayed until the early 1990's. By then, the real estate market had crashed and, in 1993, the city bought the property for $325,000. 
 Friends of the Loew's had already been inside the building, patching leaks and holding benefits in the lobby. The city leased the building to the nonprofit Jersey City Economic Development Corporation, with the agreement that the organization would work with Friends of the Loew's to renovate the theater, according to Mr. Egan, who became an employee of the development corporation. The theater got $2.5 million in outside grants, and work started on repairing the boiler, the ornate facade, the chandeliers and faux-marble columns in the lobby, the vast orchestra seating and the deep stage. 
 But Ms. Giordan and Mr. Egan soon realized that the repairs would cost more than the grant money would cover and set about recruiting volunteers. 
 Today, they are in touch with a pool of more than 4,000 supporters, Ms. Giordan said. At the height of reconstruction efforts, from 1995 to 2002, around 200 volunteers ripped down the walls dividing the orchestra pit, re-upholstered seats, painted, polished brass doors and fixtures, installed a sister pipe organ to the building's original and repaired the elevator-lift orchestra pit floor. The vintage 1929 lighting board still works. Around six feet high, it looks like a modern computer board, enlarged to respond to human hands. 
 Eric Holterman of the Princeton architecture firm Holt, Morgan, Russell helped restore the clock tower and the bronze around the front doors. ''We work on lots of historic buildings, and I'd never seen anything like the theater,'' Mr. Holterman said. ''It's in remarkable condition for its history.''
 But the theater still needs $4 million to $5 million worth of renovations. Both Friends of the Loew's and city officials see the theater as crucial to the area's revitalization. ''I worked in that theater when I was a senior in high school,'' Mr. Smith said. ''It helped keep Journal Square vibrant.''
 Sept. 28 is the 75th anniversary of the theater's opening, and Mr. Egan and Ms. Giordan hope that Friends of the Loew's will be legal occupants in time to celebrate. ''This is not the first time we've had to be patient,'' Mr. Egan said.

HEADLINE: Dreamer Wakes Up To Success

BYLINE: By RACHELLE GARBARINE

DATELINE: HAWTHORNE 

 BODY:
AT the start of a municipal court session in Hawthorne one recent night, though the judge was presiding, the prosecutor was the first to take center stage. 
 His booming voice shattered the silence. ''Do not argue with me of the plea that is offered, or you will be asking yourself, 'Why am I sitting here?''' the prosecutor, Kenneth Del Vecchio, 35, said as his dark eyes scanned the audience. 
 His audience may have been small -- it was made up of people charged with such violations as not cleaning up after a dog and shoplifting 23 deodorant sticks. But Mr. Del Vecchio, as usual, was larger than life. 
 Mr. Del Vecchio is far from your typical small-town municipal prosecutor. When he is not spending his Thursday evenings at the town courthouse, he divides his time between careers as a criminal defense lawyer, independent filmmaker -- with four movies to date -- and author. 
 He has written two criminal suspense novels, ''Revelation in the Wilderness'' (AuthorHouse) and ''Pride and Loyalty'' (AuthorHouse), which he made into movies in which he also appears. (In true Hitchcockian-fashion Mr. Del Vecchio turns up in all his flicks.) He has just completed a movie that, like his previous three, has drawn notable actors even without making it beyond the festival circuit. 
 Although Mr. Del Vecchio's professional multi-tasking seems to be paying off, in a manner of speaking, he is still looking for his breakthrough project. 
 He may have found it. For the first time, a major publisher bought a book and released it this spring. Despite its unsexy title -- ''The New Jersey Code of Criminal Justice: A Practical Guide'' (Pearson/Prentice Hall) -- the book is drawing note for its use of fiction to illustrate how state statutes apply to real-life situations. Call it Criminal Statutes for Dummies.
 So far the reviews have been good. 
 George Thomas, a professor at Rutgers Law School in Newark, said the book fills a void. No other book, he said, ''attempts to show how the statutes are used in practice.'' ''To be honest,'' he added, ''I'm jealous that I didn't come up with the idea myself.'' Anthony G. Salerno, a captain on the Asbury Park police force who also runs two test-preparation and training institutes in Howell, said the book was a useful teaching tool. 
 ''Police officers who didn't go to law school get mixed up with the complicated legalese of the statutes,'' he said. ''This book puts them into working practical terms.''
 And the publisher is pleased, too. 
 ''For a book of this type at this time it is doing beyond our expectations,'' said Korrine N. Dorsey, an assistant editor at Pearson/Prentice Hall who worked on ''The New Jersey Code of Criminal Justice.'' ''We think it is going to take off.''
 A sober, informative text may seem a departure for Mr. Del Vecchio, whose boilerplate suspense novels and films prompt comparisons to John Grisham. But he is no stranger to shifting gears. Like some of the characters in his books and movies, he is a down-to-earth, straight-talking guy.
 Just before that imposing appearance in the courtroom, he gave a summary of joking around with the cops, in R-rated language. He also cracked jokes to fill the time. 
 On first blush, his energy and directness could be seen as abrasive or brash. But behind the rough exterior, he is the kind of person who would write a ballad for Missy, his dog. And one after the other, his friends and colleagues use words like ''loyal'' and ''focused'' to describe Mr. Del Vecchio, and often settle on some variation of the phrase ''What you see is what you get.'' 
 Finbarr McCarthy, who taught Mr. Del Vecchio at Temple Law School a decade ago, says he remembers seeing a man in his undershirt sitting in the back and from time to time blurting out: ''Yeo Bar'' to get his professor's attention. 
 ''In class, he was a renegade; he liked to be outrageous and do things for the shock value,'' Mr. McCarthy said. 
 ''I wouldn't put him on the most-likely-to-succeed list in the traditional sense, but I could see Ken as a wheeler-dealer and thought he would go on to do something different.'' Small wonder. 
 Change has been a constant theme in Mr. Del Vecchio's life. He and his brother, Christian, grew up mainly in towns in Essex, Bergen, Hudson and Passaic Counties, switching elementary schools six times, twice out of state, while his mother, now an administrator for a health care clinic, and stepfather, a manager for a food distribution company, changed jobs. 
 Despite his short stints at the schools, he left his mark by becoming the class clown. ''I wanted to stand out,'' Mr. Del Vecchio said as his lips formed a devilish grin. 
 His fourth-grade teacher ''made me realize I could write,'' Mr. Del Vecchio said. By the seventh and eighth grades he was penning short stories about Salvatore, the Italian superhero, and passing them around class.
 In high school, Mr. Del Vecchio's antics got him kicked out of an all-boys prep school by his junior year. He went on to two other high schools before graduating.
 At Rutgers he majored in sociology and education -- a switch (surprise) from his initial major in economics. Despite the multiple hats, there is one sole goal. ''I was enveloped by injustices and wanted to do something about them,'' Mr. Del Vecchio said of one reason he pursued law. He said that he continued with his writing and added filmmaking because entertainment was the more effective way to make things change. 
 Along the way, he met his wife-to-be, Francine, a teacher and Columbia University doctoral candidate of tireless patience who on occasion does things like scribbling down notes if her husband has a spurt of inspiration and happens to be in the shower. 
 In the two fields for which Mr. Del Vecchio has no special training, his can-do attitude and intense focus have served him well. He has persuaded television personalities like Vincent Pastore, Big Pussy on ''The Sopranos,'' to star in his movies, and has lured a laundry list of past and present daytime soap opera stars. His latest movie, ''The Drum Beats Twice,'' a drama, also features a budding screen actress, Amy Redford -- yes Robert Redford's daughter. 
 Though he is no Steven Spielberg, he did sweet talk Eileen Fulton, a 43-year veteran of daytime soaps, to be in not one but two of his films: ''Tinsel Town'' and ''The Drum Beats Twice,'' which is to be released in about nine months. And he persuaded Sonia Satra, formerly of ''One Life to Live'' and ''Guiding Light,'' to appear in ''Pride and Loyalty'' and to be a producer as well.
 ''I totally believed he would get the film made, no matter what, which very often is not the case with independent films,'' Ms. Satra said. ''It wasn't a blockbuster,'' she conceded. ''The greater payoff was in experience.'' 
 Although Mr. Del Vecchio has not yet been able to woo a major film distributor like Miramax, he has snagged smaller ones like TapeWorm Distributors, based in Los Angeles, and EI Independent Cinema, of Butler, to distribute his movies. And he showed ''Rules for Men'' at film festivals, including the Atlantic City Film Festival, where it won best comedy in 1999. He said he would be seeking a distributor for ''The Drum Beats Twice'' when it is finished.
 Mr. Del Vecchio, who feels that the more things he tries the better his chances are that ''at least one will break through,'' finally may have a full plate. But ever the master planner, he has a back-up back-up plan: teaching. He has received a certification to teach social studies to middle and secondary school students in New Jersey. 
 That certification may just gather dust, if supporters have anything to do with it. Mr. Del Vecchio has rallied investors including John Kearney, an old law partner and buddy. 
 Mr. Del Vecchio always knew how to make money, ''to be a rainmaker,'' Mr. Kearney said. 
 ''He has been zealously working all his life to make some impression, to make a difference. Right now, he's a work in progress, but it is only a matter of time,'' Mr. Kearney said, leaving the listener to fill in the rest.

HEADLINE: Digging Deeper for a Scoop

BYLINE: By ROBERT STRAUSS

DATELINE: HAVEN BEACH 

 BODY:
EVERY summer evening, customers gather at Honey Bubbles like sprinkles on a banana split. 
 The landmark ice cream parlor -- situated on a fairly open stretch of Long Beach Boulevard midway between Ship Bottom and Beach Haven -- is known for its wide panoply of flavors and more than three dozen toppings, from Gummi Bears to Heath Bar pieces to traditional sprinkles.
 Yet this summer, despite a healthy economy and weather that has been more good than bad, the owner of Honey Bubbles, Don Meisner, could be a lot happier.
 ''I feel all beat up,'' Mr. Meisner said one recent day. ''Everything, especially everything with butter fat, is so far up in price it's unbelievable. I've had to increase just about everything 15 to 20 percent, and that isn't enough to cover costs. I already feel business slipping, just slipping away.'' 
 Call it the coastal cone crisis, or maybe the waffle cone Waterloo. Over the last few years, vacationers at the Shore have been faced with higher prices for dinners, beach tags and, to be sure, rentals. But this year, the major price rise is hitting them where it really hurts -- at their favorite ice cream joints.
 As Mr. Meisner noted, nearly everything that goes into an ice cream cone, sundae or shake is much more expensive. From milk to vanilla to butter to cocoa, various disasters and sundry excuses have driven costs skyward. The rising price of gasoline has not helped, since some distributors cite that phenomenon as a reason to raise their delivery rates.
 Consumers have noted rising prices of milk at the grocery store, but Shore purveyors of ice cream say that that is nothing compared with what they have seen on the wholesale level for the sophisticated high-fat creams they use in their businesses.
 ''Last summer, the cream we use cost $29 for five gallons,'' said Mary Goldenthal, whose family runs Springer's in Stone Harbor, where on steamy summer evenings the line winds a block or more down Third Avenue. ''Today it is $43.75 for that same five gallons.'' 
 Ms. Goldenthal said that in the preceding two decades, the price of cream had remained pretty stable, though the costs of other ingredients had risen regularly, albeit moderately.
 But then there was the price of vanilla. Madagascar, which in good years produces 60 percent of the world's supply of vanilla beans, has been hit by two devastating tropical storms in the last several years.
 ''Two years ago, the price of a gallon of extract was $65,'' said Linda Utterback, the executive director of the National Ice Cream Retailers Association in Rolling Meadows, Ill. ''Then the cyclone hit and it went to $150 a gallon. Then the new crop didn't flower properly and last year it went to $300 a gallon. In March, there was another cyclone. Now, if you can buy it, a gallon of vanilla extract is $430.''
 And, Ms. Utterback said, the cost of cocoa is at a 17-year high because of war in West Africa, particularly in Ivory Coast, as well as bad weather in South America. 
 There are some ways of getting around these rising prices, though they are not pleasant. For instance, Springer's often uses imitation vanilla. And Nagle's, an old-fashioned ice-cream parlor in Ocean Grove, buys its ingredients judiciously, concentrating on its better-selling flavors like butter pecan and mint chocolate chip, said the chef there, Nick Glaydura.
 ''But we have tried to hold the line,'' Mr. Glaydura said. ''We're still getting the same $2.30 for a single-dip cone, same as last year. Business seems pretty good, though. We have six scoopers at night and these kids have their hands pretty sore when they are finished.''
 Yet for Ms. Goldenthal of Springer's, the reasons for the sudden price increase in the kind of creams she uses are unclear.
 ''They say some of this has to do with mad cow disease in Canada and some is just because prices haven't gone up for a while, squeezing dairy farmers,'' she said. 
 Ms. Utterback said that production of some bovine growth hormones was stopped for a short time last year by the Food and Drug Administration after inconsistencies in the products were discovered. And she acknowledged that many in Canada had to stop either production or exportation of cream to the United States because of the mad cow scare.
 In addition, she said, there are fewer dairy farms in the United States these days. 
 While all these factors affect large chains like Baskin-Robbins, it is the smaller, seasonal retailers who really feel the price increases.
 ''We're like home to some people, so they are shocked when we raise prices,'' said Mr. Meisner of Honey Bubbles. He now charges $3 for his single scoops, up from $2.50 last summer. He has not raised the prices for toppings, however, and customers can still get a generous helping of Reese's pieces or various chips for 75 cents.
 ''I'm guessing that people who used to come in five times a week are now down to four,'' he said. ''That's still pretty good, but they can't be too pleased with the prices.''
 At Springer's one recent weekend, the mood was joyous, if sanguine, over the rising prices. Like Honey Bubbles, Springer's increased the price of its single cones and cups to $3 from $2.50.
 ''This is, after all, vacation,'' said Mary Jonas of Pittsburgh, who was staying in Stone Harbor for her traditional two- week family vacation. ''At least they have a reason to raise prices here. And it's such good stuff and, when you are at the Shore, even the college kids scooping the stuff night after night seem cheery.
 ''It's the price we have to pay for a good ice cream smile,'' she said.


GRAPHIC: Photo: Customers still flock to Nagle's in Ocean Grove, left, where prices have been stable only because the owners judiciously order ingredients. (Photo by Laura Pedrick for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: One Tough Week

BYLINE: By JOHN SULLIVAN

DATELINE: TRENTON 

 BODY:
AS the week wore on, the governor's warren of offices began to resemble a busy firehouse, with weary staff members pausing for a quick bite before rushing out to fight the next political blaze.
 They were still reeling from an indictment handed up the previous week charging a fund-raiser and longtime acquaintance of Governor McGreevey with shaking down a Middlesex County land owner in exchange for promises of government favors, when federal prosecutors last week announced a complaint accusing the governor's top contributor of hiring prostitutes in a blackmail scheme to foil an investigation into political fund-raising.
 And the week was still not over. On Wednesday afternoon, William D. Watley, the embattled commerce secretary, announced that he was stepping down amid a scandal over finances in his agency. 
 ''It is stunning,'' said Senator Joseph M. Kyrillos Jr., chairman of the state Republican Party. ''If someone wrote a script like this, they would be thrown out of Hollywood.''
 Even as Dr. Watley made his exit, state investigators pored over financial records from the Commerce and Economic Growth Commission. Though no one has been accused of wrongdoing, auditors have questioned contracts awarded to relatives of Dr. Watley's former chief of staff, Lesly Devereaux, and expenses charged to the commission.
 Earlier this month, the state Housing Mortgage Finance Agency canceled a $11.5 million loan for a Newark housing development proposed by an affiliate of the St. James A.M.E. Church, where Dr. Watley is pastor, after questions were raised about whether his support of the project created a conflict of interest.
 During his tenure, Dr. Watley has received mixed reviews from business groups.
 Cherie Marce, manager of government relations at the state Chamber of Commerce, said, ''I handle international trade here, and things have gone very smoothly.''
 But other corporate groups have contended that Dr. Watley was not a strong advocate for business, particularly in battles over increased state corporate taxes.
 ''The silence heard from the commerce commission during recent budget talks was deafening,'' said Richard Goldberg, president of the Commerce and Industry Association of New Jersey.
 Arguments about Dr. Watley's performance aside, the governor continues to be plagued by problems with high-level appointees. In two and a half years in office, he has watched the political explosion of the state police director, homeland security adviser, chief of staff, chief counsel and nominee to head the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey.
 ''Unfortunately, this resume with negative references on it continues to grow,'' said David Rebovich, managing director of the Rider Institute for New Jersey Politics.
 So far, the governor has argued that he had nothing to do with the most recent problems that have cropped up. In the case of Charles Kushner -- the contributor who was nominated to head the Port Authority and is accused by federal authorities of hiring prostitutes -- -- the governor and the United States attorney have both said that the case does not involve Mr. McGreevey. Still, political observers say that it will be difficult for Mr. McGreevey to distance himself from these scandals in the eyes of the voters.
 Mr. Rebovich said the governor runs the risk that people will believe ''circumstances have gotten away from him.''

HEADLINE: Sally Field's Third Career

BYLINE: By TODD S. PURDUM

DATELINE: WASHINGTON 

 BODY:
YOU know Sally Field. You should; you grew up with her. She's ''Gidget'' and ''The Flying Nun.'' She's ''Sybil'' and ''Norma Rae.'' She's the nurse's manic-depressive mother in ''E.R.'' and even the wife of the adulterous architect in Edward Albee's play ''The Goat, or Who Is Sylvia?''
 But Sally Field as Amanda Wingfield, the haunted, scheming mother in ''The Glass Menagerie''? That's a Sally Field you've never met. She is scaling the mountain of a role in a revival at the Kennedy Center that opens on Thursday and is part of the center's summer-long festival, ''Tennessee Williams Explored.'' The production, now in previews and directed by Gregory Mosher, runs through Aug. 8.
 As Stevie in Mr. Albee's play, the perfect wife of a man who just happens to fall in love with a goat, Ms. Field dazzled Broadway two years ago, delivering angry, arioso dialogue with a fierceness that surprised and delighted critics. A new career path opened up. 
 ''I have a long way to go,'' Ms. Field said over a lunch here the other day of half a Caesar salad with shrimp. ''But it's never too late to be what you might have been.''
 She began her career in silly sitcoms, but Ms. Field long ago established her acting credentials, beginning with ''Sybil,'' the groundbreaking 1976 television movie about sexual abuse and multiple-personality disorder. Still, she is quick to acknowledge that Amanda -- with her lost dreams, invalid daughter, discontented poet of a son and the ''gentleman caller'' who arrives too late to change their trapped existence -- is a special challenge.
 ''There are a handful of roles that if your heart has always been that you want to be a real actor -- what I consider that to be -- then somewhere inside you, you want to conquer a few things, to get your feet in them,'' Ms. Field said, by way of explaining why she said yes when Mr. Mosher called to offer her the part. ''And whether you ever conquer them, I don't know. It's like saying you want to conquer 'Hamlet' or 'Medea' or 'King Lear.' You just want to start trying.''
 Ms. Field has wanted to start trying for years. In the late 1960's, miserable in her second hit sitcom, as Sister Bertrille in ''The Flying Nun,'' she went one night with Madeleine Sherwood, the Broadway veteran who played her Mother Superior, to the Hollywood branch of the Actor's Studio. It was the start of a long education with the teacher Lee Strasberg -- and of a dual acting existence that in some ways persisted through three decades of increasingly demanding television and movie roles, culminating in her Broadway debut as Mercedes Ruehl's replacement in ''The Goat.''
 ''I lived this very odd life of doing 'The Flying Nun' in the day and, literally, Sartre, at night,'' Ms. Field recalled. ''And I'm not saying I understood it. But I wanted to do things like 'The Respectful Prostitute,' '' by Sartre. ''It was a very important time in my life.''
 Ms. Field has now been famous for almost 40 years. She has two Oscars and two Emmys. She looks younger than her 57 years, with no obvious help beyond good genes, good diet and good luck. Again and again, audiences and critics have proved that they like her -- they really, well, you know.
 But given the cultural and economic realities of Hollywood, the scripts she gets now are not so great. ''Oh, just awful ones!'' she said, laughing. ''You know, somebody's mother that's either no character whatsoever, or so demeaning in that it's usually very poorly written -- just stupid. So many of them are like the bad mother -- which would be fun -- but it's just badly written, taking a lot of cliches from a lot of other bad cliches.''
 So it is perhaps not surprising that she has chosen to spend her summer playing Amanda, that daunting, dramatic mother. In his original stage directions, Williams described her as ''a little woman of great but confused vitality clinging frantically to another time and place,'' whose characterization ''must be carefully created, not copied from type.''
 Mr. Mosher, a longtime director and occasional producer, said he had not initially thought of Ms. Field. ''I knew I was going to be spoiled for choice,'' he said. ''I was in no rush and I just waited for it to bubble to my subconscious. And then one night in the middle of the night I just thought: 'Duh! Sally Field!' I had not seen her in 'The Goat.' I must confess I've never seen 'The Flying Nun' or 'Gidget.' But 'Norma Rae,' '' he said, of the 1979 movie about a textile worker trying to unionize a mill in the South, ''is one of the great, great American movies. That's my memory of her, as this fighter. This tiny fighter.''
 Amanda is nothing if not a fighter. The role was created by Laurette Taylor, a faded, alcoholic star making a final comeback in a performance that remains a Broadway legend -- one that the late Martin Ritt, the director of ''Norma Rae,'' saw and described to Ms. Field often. ''I guess it was just this monumental performance,'' she said.
 ''It's a beautiful play,'' Ms. Field added. ''I just have to do the work and try really hard to get out of its way and not put too much pressure on it. It will just simply be my first version of Amanda. Maybe there will be a fifth and a sixth version.''
 Ms. Field grew up the child of journeyman actors and has been a working actress herself since graduating from high school. She has survived two marriages, a high-profile romance with her ''Smokey and the Bandit'' co-star, Burt Reynolds, and mostly single motherhood of three sons -- a reality that resonates with Amanda's solitary efforts to find ''Happiness! Good Fortune!'' for her children. In the current production they are played by Jennifer Dundas and Jason Butler Harner, with Corey Brill as the gentleman caller.
 Asked what was the worst thing that had ever happened to her, Ms. Field first said she was ''too superstitious to say,'' then went on: ''I have never had my heart broken. That's probably the worst thing that's ever happened to me, that I haven't allowed my heart to be broken. I think that's very sad.'' She paused, then broke into that wide grin of hers, and added: ''I have broken a few. Said in true Amanda form!''
 Ms. Field said that Mr. Strasberg had long recommended some form of analysis to help actors ''understand their own process,'' and that she had been in and out of psychotherapy over the years. ''Oh, please!'' she said. ''I invented it.'' Asked if she had had a complicated family life, she replied matter-of-factly: ''Well, who has an easy situation? Did you?''
 ''I think people who have the hardest time getting over a lot of the imprints that their childhood gave them are people who didn't have anything overtly difficult,'' she added. ''And the persistence of behavioral patterns that are handed down from generations is impossible. We spend our entire adult lifetime trying to understand it, and overcome it, and be better than it, so that we can then change the pattern or try to hand on something a little more productive to our children. And I'm sure we don't. We just hand on a little diverse variation. 
 ''But that's why Tennessee Williams is Tennessee Williams, because that's what he wrote about. I mean, that's what 'Glass Menagerie' is: how do you love and hate the same people, all in the same breath, all at the same time?''

SECTION: Section 7; Column 1; Book Review Desk; SCIENCE FICTION; Pg. 19

LENGTH: 1094 words

BYLINE: By Gerald Jonas

 BODY:
IRON COUNCIL, by China Mieville (Del Rey/Ballantine, $24.95), is an exemplar of what some are calling the Next Wave in British science fiction. The name is a sly reference to the New Wave of the 1960's, when English and American writers as varied as Michael Moorcock, J. G. Ballard, Harlan Ellison and Samuel R. Delany cast a suspicious eye on genre staples like space travel and future technology. The Next Wave -- which, depending on who's counting, includes British novelists like M. John Harrison, Richard K. Morgan and Neal Asher -- mixes left-leaning politics and a taste for horror into cautionary tales of societies gone wrong at the core. 
 ''Iron Council'' is set in an imaginary world dominated by the city of New Crobuzon, a corrupt center of power clearly inspired by Charles Dickens's London. Science and technology play an important role in New Crobuzon; the book's central metaphor is an attempt to drive a rail line through the unexplored continent beyond the city's borders. But real power lies in the wielding of magic. While golems and hexes and other conceits from European mythology figure prominently, these myths have been stripped of all traces of religious allegory. Without ever spelling out the details (any more than Isaac Asimov explained the intricacies of his robots' ''positronic brains''), Mieville treats magic as another form of technology, one that follows dimly apprehended rules and that typically exacts a cost greater than its practitioners anticipate.
 In an instructive parallel to slavery in the antebellum South, the economy of New Crobuzon seems to rely on the labor of the Remade -- criminals ''reconfigured in the city's punishment factories'' into nightmare chimeras, part human, part animal, part machine. Chain gangs of Remades are sent to work on the transcontinental railway, side by side with human laborers and members of New Crobuzon's many ''xenian'' species -- sentient creatures that resemble frogs and birds and insect-humanoid hybrids.
 Mieville feels no need to explain the presence of the xenians in New Crobuzon; they are as much a part of his imaginary society as the magic-empowered militia that enforces the dictates of the ruling elite. What concerns him is the emergence of a serious resistance movement. When oppressed humans overcome their ingrained loathing of the Remade and the xenians to make common cause against the powers that be, Mieville invests their rising with a historical poignancy that by no means ensures its success. To convey both the weirdness and the familiarity of his vividly elaborated world, he peppers his sentences with unusual words (''serein,'' ''strath,'' ''atramentous,'' ''cuneal'') that will send most readers to a good unabridged dictionary -- and back again to this challenging but deeply rewarding novel.
 Ken MacLeod is another British novelist with a bent for political science fiction. But if ''Iron Council'' offers a primer on how to use an imaginary society to dramatize real issues, MacLeod's NEWTON'S WAKE (Tor/Tom Doherty, $24.95) amply demonstrates the pitfalls of this approach. 
 Set in a future of faster-than-light starships, other-dimensional doorways between distant worlds, and computers that have achieved not only sentience but transcendence, this novel asks us to care about characters whose problems are as incomprehensible as their technology. In between space battles played as much for laughs as for suspense, many pages are devoted to a political debate about whether or not to return to an earth left largely empty by departing ''posthuman'' intelligences that were once computers. The passion with which both sides marshal their arguments is belied by MacLeod's failure to provide us with enough background to understand what is at stake. 
 Instead of doing the hard work of story-telling, MacLeod wastes his energies on unlikely set pieces, like strained parodies of agitprop drama in pseudo-Shakespearean diction; the hardly fresh humor here is that the far-future playwrights get their historical sources thoroughly muddled, as in ''The Tragedy of Leonid Brezhnev, Prince of Muscovy.'' Like a thought experiment with too many variables, ''Newton's Wake'' itself dissolves into a muddle of scenes that were evidently more fun to write than they are to read.
 CAMOUFLAGE, by Joe Haldeman (Ace, $23.95), asks little of the reader but a temporary suspension of disbelief. Millenniums ago, not one but two shape-changing aliens came to earth for reasons unknown. One, whom Haldeman calls ''the changeling,'' forgets its origins but learns to survive by taking the shape of creatures at the top of the nearest food chain, becoming in turn a great white shark, a killer whale, a porpoise and eventually a human being. While it struggles to blend into the culture of Southern California circa 1931, its long-range goal is to find another of its kind. Meanwhile, a second shape-changing creature from afar, whom Haldeman calls ''the chameleon,'' has learned to blend into human societies very well, usually as a soldier because it gets pleasure from inflicting pain. 
 This is the sketchy back story. The actual plot is driven by the discovery, on the floor of a trench seven miles down in the Pacific, of a seemingly impermeable artifact of presumably extraterrestrial origin. To probe the artifact, a former admiral puts together a team that includes the noted marine biologist who raised the Titanic.
 The narration switches among three points of view. Two serial flashbacks trace the experiences of the shape-changers before the discovery of the artifact, while a contemporary thread, set in the years 2019-21, follows the attempts of the exploration team to crack open the mysterious object. In time, the reader begins to wonder if the team includes one or both of the shape-changers. 
 Haldeman handles this complicated scheme effortlessly, and the ending is satisfying whether or not you have figured out who is who. If this smoothly written entertainment has a flaw, it is in the take-it-or-leave-it premise. I had no more trouble accepting two shape-changers than one. What gave me pause was the assumption that while some shape-changing aliens are capable of being changed by their experiences, others are simply born bad. 
 THE BRILLIANCE OF THE MOON, by Lian Hearn (Riverhead, $24.95), is a worthy conclusion to an inventive trilogy that the pseudonymous author calls ''Tales of the Otori''; all three volumes are set in an imaginary medieval Japan where some people, including the hero, Takeo, are capable of truly mind-bending powers. 

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

DOCUMENT-TYPE: Review

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

HEADLINE: An Office District Slow in Emerging

BYLINE: By JOHN HOLUSHA

 BODY:
Decades-long efforts to develop Long Island City as a major office district received a bit of a boost last week with the news that Citigroup would move 700 employees from Lower Manhattan into a planned new 14-story building across the street from the company's 48-story tower, which has stood in splendid isolation since the late 1980's.
 Still, the effort has a long way to go.
 Long Island City has for years been designated by planners as a potential fourth central business district for the city, after Midtown and downtown Manhattan and downtown Brooklyn. Citigroup put up its 48-story tower in 1989, and earlier this year Metropolitan Life moved 1,600 employees into two renovated factory buildings in the area. 
 Much of the area was rezoned a few years ago to allow larger office buildings, and a pending additional rezoning, mainly on the edges of the previous district, would permit more residential development and larger supermarkets. 
 The proposal has been approved by the local community board and the borough president's office and awaits hearings before the City Council.
 Amanda M. Burden, chairwoman of the City Planning Commission, said the zoning change is intended to encourage low-rise residential and retail development in Hunters Point. ''We expect that this will trigger high-density office and residential development along Jackson Avenue by making the area more attractive,'' she said.
 In anticipation of zoning changes, developers have been buying old industrial buildings for use as art galleries and schools -- and possibly as residences if the changes are approved. 
 In one notable recent sale, the owners of the Scalamandre silk mill in Long Island City announced early this year that they were moving to South Carolina, and the old mill buildings were bought by a Manhattan-based developer, Time Equities. Francis J. Greenburger, the company's president, said Scalamandre would retain part of the space and the rest would be offered to commercial tenants, although he did not rule out a residential conversion eventually. In the 1980's Time Equities was a major converter of rental buildings to co-ops. 
 Some properties have already undergone conversion. The former Lion Match factory, a four-story, 60,000-square-foot building on 43rd Avenue, is being renovated for use as offices. A four-story, 130,000-square-foot building on 21st Street that lost its manufacturing tenants is now the Information Technology High School.
 The economics driving conversion are compelling in areas zoned for housing or likely to be rezoned, said Richard Maltz, chairman of Greiner-Maltz, an industrial and commercial broker active in Queens, Brooklyn and Long Island.
 He said a typical 10,000-square-foot factory building in the area sells for $120 to $140 a square foot, or $1.2 million to $1.4 million. But if a builder can put up 30,000 square feet of residential space on that same site, Mr. Maltz said, the value of the property rises to $2.1 million to $2.5 million. 
 The manufacturers still in the once solidly industrial area are complaining that the zoning changes, if approved, may drive them from the area, which is prized for its proximity to customers in Manhattan.
 Adam Friedman, executive director of the New York Industrial Retention Network, a not-for-profit organization that seeks to assist manufacturers in the city, said there is a danger that adding office workers and residents to the area will significantly change the nature of the community. If that happens, manufacturing buildings will be sold for conversion or rents will increase beyond the financial ability of small artisans or distributors.
 ''There are still 27,000 industrial jobs in the 11101 ZIP code area,'' covering Long Island City and parts of some nearby neighborhoods, Mr. Friedman said. 
 Mr. Friedman said city planners had not accepted his organization's proposal to designate a part of the area as an industrial employment district to reduce the pressure on owners to sell to developers.
 Some people, however, doubt that there is that much demand for the existing manufacturing space. Gail A. Roseman, an executive vice president of Sholom & Zuckerbrot, a commercial brokerage in Long Island City, said, ''The area has changed, and the need for manufacturing buildings is not there anymore.'' 
 John Reinertsen, a vice president of CB Richard Ellis, a major commercial property broker, agreed. The overall situation in the area, he said, is ''too much space chasing too few tenants.'' He said he expected that some of the industrial space would be preserved but that ''over time a lot will become residential.''
 The ideal might be a balance, but achieving it is complex. Robert Yaro, president of the Regional Plan Association, a private planning group, said: ''We have learned that the most successful business districts are those that are the most diverse. The challenge is to allow for evolution in Long Island City, but also create certainty for the industrial sector.''
 Despite the general decline of industry in the city, Mr. Yaro said, manufacturing and distribution still provide about 20 percent of the jobs in the city -- jobs that are often the first rung on the economic ladder for recent immigrants.
 Mr. Maltz said that low interest rates were partly behind the efforts to buy and redevelop industrial properties and that prices might start to decline if rates rise and developers find they cannot get the financing for a major conversion project.
 The proposed rezoning will allow for mixed-use development, with housing and stores adjacent to warehouses and manufacturing, said David H. Inerfeld, a senior director of Sholom & Zuckerbrot. But this will be nothing new for the area, where a typical block may already have industrial buildings on the corners and row houses covering the midblock area. Most of this varied development predates zoning rules.
 Residential development will attract retailers to serve a growing population, and this will make the area more livable, Mr. Reinertsen said. ''Right now, the area pretty much shuts down in the evening.''

HEADLINE: A Market Forecast Takes a Long View, and a Dismal One It Is

BYLINE: By MARK HULBERT. 
Mark Hulbert is editor of The Hulbert Financial Digest, a service of CBS MarketWatch. E-mail: strategy@nytimes.com.

 BODY:
THE stock market in the summer of 2008 is likely to be only barely higher than it is today.
 That disheartening prediction comes from a market-timing model with an excellent record of forecasting four-year stock market returns. The model is based on projections from analysts at Value Line for price changes over the next three to five years in the 1,700 stocks they monitor. The median of those projections is published each week in the Value Line Investment Survey. 
 Value Line doesn't advise investors about how to interpret this statistic. But since 1968, when Value Line began publishing it, low readings have generally been followed by mediocre stock market returns over the next four years. Similarly, high readings have typically been followed by above-average returns over similar periods.
 To be sure, the Value Line numbers haven't been very accurate in forecasting short-term market moves. But they have been quite reliable in predicting the longer term.
 They have proved particularly useful when the mood of investors reaches extremes of euphoria or despair. Value Line's median projection was last considered in this column on Sept. 30, 2001, less than three weeks after the terrorist attacks. At that writing, the indicator was at 105, its highest in more than a decade. At the time, many investors were unwilling to make any bets on the stock market, but those who relied on that high reading to invest in equities have been rewarded. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index has produced a cumulative total return of 20 percent since Sept. 21, 2001, the day of the market's post-attack lows. 
 Unfortunately for market bulls, however, the Value Line reading has now sunk to 50, a very low level. Over the last 36 years, in fact, the reading has been lower just 11percent of the time. 
 The indicator has limits, of course. It's hardly foolproof. And because it focuses on median performance, it is not helpful in projecting how large-capitalization stocks will perform relative to small caps. If the large caps lead the market over the next four years, indexes that are dominated by the large caps -- like the S.&P. 500 -- will do better than the indicator suggests.
 Credit for realizing the indicator's market-timing power is shared by at least two people, who independently reported on its usefulness in the mid-1980's. The first is Daniel A. Seiver, an economics professor at Miami University in Ohio and the editor of the PAD System Report, an investment newsletter. The second is Peter L. Bernstein, the founding editor of The Journal of Portfolio Management and now the head of a consulting firm that bears his name.
 Professor Seiver is so confident about the indicator's market-timing powers that he bases his newsletter's market-timing advice on it. He considers any reading of 100 or more to be a buy signal, for example, while he uses a reading of 50 or below as an occasion to build a large cash position in his model portfolio. Based on the current reading of 50, Professor Seiver is recommending being only 50 percent invested in stocks. And he says he will not advocate reinvesting any of that cash in the stock market until Value Line's median projection rises back to at least 100.
 Professor Seiver says several factors help explain the indicator's usefulness. First, he says he finds that Value Line stock analysts tend to be ''less susceptible to valuation manias'' than most other analysts, because Value Line's are independent, immune from the pressures that can be found in research departments associated with investment banks and brokerage firms.
 A second factor, he said, is that few other firms besides Value Line even bother to focus on what will happen in three to five years, concentrating instead on just the next 12 months. Because so few other analysts are looking so far ahead, Value Line's researchers should find it relatively easy to spot profit opportunities. 
 ''Wall Street is certainly myopic,'' he said. ''Anyone who is willing to focus on the longer term should be able to earn a bonus for doing so.''
 A third factor, Professor Seiver said, is the ''law of large numbers,'' which holds that random errors become insignificant when focusing on many observations. He has no doubt that many Value Line projections of individual stocks' three-to-five year returns are wide of the mark. But because the median projection is the distillation of nearly 2,000 separate forecasts, he said, ''the analysts' errors will tend to cancel each other out.'' 
 And for now, the overall forecast suggests that investors should not be too optimistic about the stock market.

SECTION: Section 1; Column 1; National Desk; Pg. 1

LENGTH: 3592 words

HEADLINE: As Police Use of Tasers Soars, Questions Over Safety Emerge

BYLINE: By ALEX BERENSON; Eric Dash contributed reporting from New York for this article.

DATELINE: NAZARETH, Pa. 

 BODY:
As the sun set on June 24, something snapped in Kris J. Lieberman, an unemployed landscaper who lived a few miles from this quiet town. For 45 minutes, he crawled deliriously around a pasture here, moaning and pounding his head against the weedy ground.
 Eventually the police arrived, carrying a Taser M26, an electric gun increasingly popular with law enforcement officers nationwide. The gun fires electrified barbs up to 21 feet, hitting suspects with a disabling charge.
 The officers told Mr. Lieberman, 32, to calm down. He lunged at them instead. They fired their Taser twice. He fought briefly, collapsed and died. 
 Mr. Lieberman joined a growing number of people, now at least 50, including 6 in June alone, who have died since 2001 after being shocked. Taser International, which makes several versions of the guns, says its weapons are not lethal, even for people with heart conditions or pacemakers. The deaths resulted from drug overdoses or other factors and would have occurred anyway, the company says.
 But Taser has scant evidence for that claim. The company's primary safety studies on the M26, which is far more powerful than other stun guns, consist of tests on a single pig in 1996 and on five dogs in 1999. Company-paid researchers, not independent scientists, conducted the studies, which were never published in a peer-reviewed journal. Taser has no full-time medical director and has never created computer models to simulate the effect of its shocks, which are difficult to test in human clinical trials for ethical reasons.
 What is more, aside from a continuing Defense Department study, the results of which have not been released, no federal or state agencies have studied the safety, or effectiveness, of Tasers, which fall between two federal agencies and are essentially unregulated. Nor has any federal agency studied the deaths to determine what caused them. In at least two cases, local medical examiners have said Tasers were partly responsible. In many cases, autopsies are continuing or reports are unavailable.
 The few independent studies that have examined the Taser have found that the weapon's safety is unproven at best. The most comprehensive report, by the British government in 2002, concluded ''the high-power Tasers cannot be classed, in the vernacular, as 'safe.' '' Britain has not approved Tasers for general police use.
 A 1989 Canadian study found that stun guns induced heart attacks in pigs with pacemakers. A 1999 study by the Department of Justice on an electrical weapon much weaker than the Taser found that it might cause cardiac arrest in people with heart conditions. In reviewing other electrical devices, the Food and Drug Administration has found that a charge half as large as that of the M26 can be dangerous to the heart. 
 While Taser says that the M26 is not dangerous, it now devotes most of its marketing efforts to the X26, a less powerful weapon it introduced last year. Both weapons are selling briskly. About 100,000 officers nationally now have Tasers, 20 times the number in 2000, and most carry the M26. Taser, whose guns are legal for civilian use in most states, hopes to expand its potential market with a new consumer version of the X26 later this summer.
 For Taser, which owns the weapon's trademark and is the only company now making the guns, the growth has been a bonanza. Its stock has soared. Its executives and directors, including a former New York police commissioner, Bernard B. Kerik, have taken advantage, selling $60 million in shares since November. 
 Patrick Smith, Taser's chief executive, said the guns are safe. ''We tell people that this has never caused a death, and in my heart and soul I believe that's true,'' Mr. Smith said.
 Taser did not need to disclose the British results to American police departments, he said. ''The Brits are extremely conservative,'' he said. ''To me, this is sort of boilerplate, the fine print.'' In addition to Taser's animal trials, thousands of police volunteers have received shocks without harm, Mr. Smith said.
 But the hits that police officers receive from the M26 in their Taser training have little in common with the shocks given to suspects. In training, volunteers usually receive a single shock of a half-second or less. In the field, Tasers automatically fire for five seconds. If an officer holds down the trigger, a Taser will discharge longer. And suspects are often hit repeatedly.
 Over all, Taser has significantly overstated the weapon's safety, say biomedical engineers who separately examined the company's research at the request of The New York Times. None of the engineers have any financial stake in the company or any connection with Taser; The Times did not pay them.
 Relatively small electric shocks can kill people whose hearts are weakened by disease or cocaine use, said John Wikswo, a Vanderbilt University biomedical engineer. But no one knows whether the Taser's current crosses the threshold for those people, Dr. Wikswo said.
 ''Their testing scheme has not included the possibility that there is a subset of the population that is exquisitely sensitive,'' Dr. Wikswo said. ''That alone means they have not done adequate testing.''
 Mr. Smith said Taser would eventually run more tests. ''In a perfect world, I'd love to have studies on all this stuff, but animal studies are controversial, expensive,'' he said. ''You've got to do the reasonable amount of testing.'' Comparing Taser's tests with the studies conducted by makers of medical devices like pacemakers is unfair, he said.
 Dr. Andrew Podgorski, a Canadian electrical engineer who conducted the 1989 study, said he was certain that Tasers were dangerous for people with pacemakers. More research is needed to determine if other people are vulnerable, he said. 
 ''I would urge the U.S. government to conduct those studies,'' Dr. Podgorski said. ''Shocking a couple of pigs and dogs doesn't prove anything.''

In More Officers' Hands
 Many police officers defend the Taser, saying the weapon helps them avoid using deadly force and lowers the risk of injury to officers. Tasers let police officers subdue suspects without wrestling with or hitting them, said David Klinger, a former police officer and a criminology professor at the University of Missouri at St. Louis. And Tasers are surely safer than firearms. 
 ''I think it is appropriate for deployment in the field,'' Mr. Klinger said. ''You trust this guy or gal with a gun, you should be able to trust them with a less lethal device.'' 
 But human rights groups say the police may be overusing the Taser. Because the gun leaves only light marks, and because Taser markets it as nonlethal, officers often use it on unruly suspects, not just as an alternative to deadly force, said Dr. William F. Schulz, the executive director of Amnesty International USA. In recent incidents, officers have shocked a 9-year-old girl in Arizona and a 66-year-old woman in Kansas City. 
 ''We think there should be controlled, systematic independent medical studies,'' Dr. Schulz said. ''We would like to see these weapons suspended until these questions are answered.''
 A study by the Orange County, Fla., sheriff's office showed that officers used pepper spray and batons much less after getting the guns. But the use of Tasers more than made up for that drop, and the department's overall use of force increased 58 percent from 2000 to 2003. Last week, several police departments in Orange County agreed to restrict the use of Tasers to situations where suspects are actively resisting officers. The sheriff's office is not part of the agreement and says it is still studying the matter.
 State and federal agencies do not keep tabs on Taser use, so no one knows how many times officers have fired the weapon. Officers have reported close to 5,000 uses of the M26 to Taser, but the company says the actual number is much higher.
 Little evidence supports the theory that Tasers reduce police shootings or work better than other alternatives to guns, like pepper spray. Because of their limited range, Tasers are best in situations where an officer using a Taser is covered by another with a firearm, officers say.
 A 2002 company study found that nearly 85 percent of people shocked with Tasers were unarmed. Fewer than 5 percent were carrying guns.
 In Phoenix, which has equipped all its officers with Tasers, police shootings fell by half last year. Taser trumpets that statistic on its Web site. But last year's drop appears to be an anomaly. This year, shootings are running at a record pace, according to the Phoenix police department.
 A 2002 study in Greene County, Mo., found that Tasers were only marginally more effective than pepper spray at restraining suspects. Pepper spray worked in 91 percent of cases, while the Taser had a 94 percent success rate.
 The largest police departments have been slow to embrace the Taser. The New York Police Department owns only a handful of Tasers, which are used by specialized units and supervisors, a spokesman said. 

'Gold in Those Hills'
 The M26 was introduced only five years ago, but the technology is much older. John Cover, an Arizona inventor, created the Taser in 1969. Its name stands for ''Thomas A. Swift Electric Rifle,'' an allusion to the Tom Swift series of science fiction novels.
 Engineers have known for generations that relatively small electric currents cause painful and uncontrollable muscle contractions. Tasers operate on that principle, firing barbs that are connected by wire to the gun and flood the body with current. The gun can deliver its shock even if the barbs do not break the skin because its current can jump through two inches of clothing.
 Weak currents are not inherently dangerous if they stop in a few minutes. But stronger shocks can disrupt the electrical circuitry of the heart. That condition, ventricular fibrillation, causes cardiac arrest in seconds and death in minutes, unless the heart is defibrillated with an even larger shock. 
 The exact current needed to cause fibrillation depends on technical factors like the current's shape and frequency, as well as the heart's condition, said James Eason, a biomedical engineering professor at Washington and Lee University. But because fibrillation is so dangerous, scientists can conduct only limited human trials. They must estimate the threshold of fibrillation from animal trials and computer models.
 Still, the broad parameters for fibrillation are known, and the first Taser from Mr. Cover had a large safety margin. In 1975 the Consumer Product Safety Commission concluded that weapon, which was 11 percent as powerful as the M26, probably would not harm healthy humans.
 Then, in March 1976, the Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco and Firearms claimed it had jurisdiction over the weapons because gunpowder propelled their barbs. The firearms bureau essentially outlawed them for civilian use; no federal safety standard was ever created. 
 But the original Tasers were bulky and often ineffective. For almost two decades, they remained a niche product used by a few police departments.
 That began to change after 1993, when Mr. Smith and his brother Thomas created a company to market electric weapons to civilians. Patrick Smith, who had just graduated from the University of Chicago business school, saw enormous potential for an alternative to firearms.
 ''I just figured I'm going to go to out to Arizona, and I'm going to scratch and sniff and dig, and figure there's going to be gold in those hills,'' Mr. Smith said in an interview.
 In January 1995, the Smiths introduced their first electric gun, which was powered by compressed nitrogen. As a result, the weapon was not regulated by the firearms bureau and could be sold to civilians. 
 For the next several years, the company struggled, as concerns over the gun's power kept sales slow. By 1999, the company, now known as Taser International, was near bankruptcy, with only $50,000 in the bank and $2.7 million in debt.
 ''It was pretty humiliating,'' he said. ''We had completely wiped out my parents financially.''

Testing
 Hoping to stay afloat, the company introduced the Advanced Taser M26 in December 1999. The weapon closely resembled a handgun, a feature many police officers liked, and was very powerful. 
 According to Taser, the gun produced 26 watts of power, four times the power of the earlier model. A field test in 2001 by the Canadian police showed that the M26 was even stronger, with an output of 39 watts.
 (Stun gun power is usually gauged in watts, a measure of electrical energy, even though the biological effects of electricity are more closely related to current strength, measured in amperes. Electrical engineers often compare the flow of electricity to a river: amperes are like the river's speed, while watts are the amount of water flowing by each second. As watts increase, amperes rise, but more slowly.)
 Taser's sales rose as officers learned about the new gun. At meetings with police officers, company representatives encouraged them to receive a half-second shock to feel the weapon's power for themselves. ''These guys would leave just absolutely evangelical about the product because we would just drop them all,'' Mr. Smith said.
 In its marketing, the company touted the safety of the M26, saying it had been extensively tested.
 But Taser had performed only two animal studies before introducing the M26.
 In 1996, Taser hired Robert Stratbucker, a Nebraska doctor and farmer, to test the weapon. Dr. Stratbucker, who is now Taser's part-time medical director, shocked a pig 48 times with shocks as large as those from the M26. The pig suffered no heart damage.
 Three years later, the company hired Dr. Stratbucker and Dr. Wayne McDaniel, an electrical engineer, for an animal test at the University of Missouri. The scientists shocked five anesthetized dogs about 200 times with the M26. The dogs did not suffer cardiac arrest, although one animal had changes in its heartbeat, according to a report.
 Taser has repeatedly said the studies proved that the M26 was safe. But the biomedical engineers who reviewed the gun's safety for The Times said Taser should have conducted far more research.
 ''I don't think there has been a definitive study saying that yes it can contribute to death or no it cannot,'' said Dr. Raymond Ideker, an electrophysiologist and a professor in the cardiology division at the University of Alabama at Birmingham. Taser must test more animals and vary the shocks they receive to find the gun's safety margin, Dr. Ideker said.
 In addition, while Taser claims that its Missouri study proves that the gun is safe for people who have used cocaine, it never tested animals dosed with cocaine. Because cocaine substantially increases heart attack risk, and Tasers are used on people who have taken cocaine, that omission is a serious flaw, said Dr. Wikswo of Vanderbilt.
 The company should also examine risks other than fibrillation, some scientists say.
 Dr. Terrence Allen, a former medical examiner in Los Angeles who examined cases in the late 1980's when people died after being shocked with earlier-model Tasers, said he was sure the weapons could be lethal. Taser is misrepresenting the medical evidence, said Dr. Allen, who has consulted for people who have sued the company. 
 Dr. Mark W. Kroll, a Taser director and the chief technology officer of St. Jude Medical, one of the largest pacemaker manufacturers, said Taser had adequately tested its weapons and they were safe. External pacemakers deliver much larger charges and do not cause fibrillation, he said.
 Dr. Ideker countered that pacemakers and Tasers could not be easily compared, because the Taser's shock is very short and powerful, while a pacemaker delivers its charge over a much longer period.
 Although Taser has performed only rudimentary studies of the M26, it has more closely studied the X26, the gun it introduced last year. In a 2003 study at the University of Missouri, Taser found that a shock roughly 20 times that of the X26 caused a healthy, anesthetized 85-pound pig to fibrillate.
 Mr. Smith cites the 2003 Missouri study as proof that all Tasers have a safety margin of 20-to-1 or more. But the new gun puts out a charge only one-fourth as large as the older model, a fact Taser does not generally advertise. 
 The study said nothing about the M26, or about hearts stressed by disease, drugs or physical activity. ''I think another test is warranted,'' Dr. Ideker said. 
 Taser did not test the older gun, which is associated with nearly all the deaths, because ''we believed that the M26's safety record and prior testing speaks for itself,'' Mr. Smith said. ''Could it be done? Absolutely. There's time and expense involved.''
 The X26 has become Taser's biggest seller, based mainly on the company's claims that it is even stronger than the M26 despite its small size and lower power. The company says the new gun enables electrical current to enter the body more efficiently.
 No independent agency has tested the guns side by side, and in Taser's patent on the M26, Mr. Smith himself argued that weaker guns were often ineffective because they do not deliver enough current to incapacitate suspects. But neither deaths nor concerns about effectiveness have dampened police support and investor enthusiasm for Taser International. Stock analysts predict Taser will have $15 million in profits on sales of $60 million in 2004. Investors have bid up the company's shares 60-fold since last February, giving Taser a value of $1.2 billion.
 The Smith brothers and their father, Phillips, have sold $46 million in Taser shares since November, according to federal filings. They still own $130 million worth of shares. Other Taser executives and directors have sold $14 million in stock. Mr. Kerik, the former New York police commissioner and a director, has sold $900,000 in stock. Mr. Kroll of St. Jude Medical has sold $1.7 million. 
 ''It's been great,'' Patrick Smith said of the company's recent success. But making money is not his main goal, he said. ''If we could get a Taser on every officer's belt,'' he said, '' it would save hundreds of lives or thousands of lives a year.''

Deaths and Questions
 Meanwhile, the number of Taser-associated deaths is rising. In June alone, at least six people died, the most ever in one month: Eric B. Christmas, James A. Cobb, Jacob J. Lair, Anthony C. Oliver, Jerry W. Pickens and Mr. Lieberman.
 The circumstances of the deaths vary widely. Among the six, Mr. Pickens was the only one hit with the X26. 
 Mr. Cobb fought for several minutes after being shocked, which suggests that fibrillation could not have caused his death. Some of the other men collapsed immediately, according to news reports and witnesses. Some of the men were fighting with the police when officers shot them. Others simply refused to obey orders.
 Mr. Pickens was one. On June 4, in Bridge City, La., the police were summoned to help calm him after an argument with his 18-year-old son, Taylor Pickens. Jerry Pickens confronted the police in the family's front yard.
 ''My dad, he had been drinking, and he was kind of hostile toward the police,'' Taylor said. ''He kept trying to go back inside the house, and they said, 'If you're going to go back into the house we're going to Taser you.''' Mr. Pickens who was unarmed, began to walk inside, Taylor said.
 ''They counted down three, and then they shot him in the back,'' Taylor said. ''My dad stiffened up, and fell back.'' Mr. Pickens hit his head on a cement walkway and began foaming at the mouth, Taylor said.
 Sharon Landis, Taylor's mother and Mr. Pickens's wife, said officers did not need to shock her husband. ''They could have pepper-sprayed him, they could have grabbed him,'' she said. ''He's 55 years old, and these are big burly cops.''
 Mr. Pickens was pronounced brain-dead that day and removed from life support three days later, Ms. Landis said.
 Toxicologic tests on Mr. Pickens are being conducted, said Gayle Day of the Jefferson Parish coroner's office. A spokesman for the sheriff's office said he could not comment on a continuing investigation. Mr. Smith said he could not comment on Mr. Pickens's death.
 Three weeks later, Kris Lieberman died in Pennsylvania. The officers who shocked him were the only witnesses to his death, which the Pennsylvania State Police are investigating. But Mr. Lieberman's parents said the state police told them that their son was shocked twice and collapsed afterward. [Stan Coopersmith, chief of the Bushkill Township Police, whose officers responded to the call, said he could not comment on the incident until the state police finish their investigation.] But Taser said that the police chief had told the company that Mr. Lieberman fought briefly after the shocks and that an automatic defibrillator used by the officers indicated Mr. Lieberman was not fibrillating when he collapsed.
 ''I would suspect the autopsy will find a cause of death that does not include the Taser,'' Mr. Smith said.
 Mr. Lieberman's parents say that he was troubled but that he did not use drugs. Police officers searched Mr. Lieberman's home after the shooting and did not find drugs, his parents say. Toxicologic tests are pending, the Northampton County Coroner said.
 Mr. Lieberman's father, Richard, a plain-spoken farmer, said he had not decided whether to hire a lawyer. He simply wants to know if the gun caused his son's death. ''If he was the problem, we have to accept it,'' Mr. Lieberman said. ''If they were the problem, they have to accept it.''

HEADLINE: Sahar Usmani, Josiah Brown

 BODY:
Sahar Usmani, a molecular geneticist, and Josiah Henry Brown, an educational administrator, were married on Friday. The Rev. John F. Smith, an Episcopal priest, performed the nondenominational ceremony at Lighthouse Point Park in New Haven. 
 Mrs. Brown, 30, is a postdoctoral associate in epidemiology and public health at Yale. She graduated from Jamia Millia Islamia, a university in New Delhi, where she also received a master's degree in biosciences. She has a doctoral degree in population genetics from Universiti Putra Malaysia in Serdang. Her parents, Tasneem and Qamar N. Usmani, live in New Delhi. The bride's father is a professor of theoretical physics at Jamia Millia Islamia. Her mother is a professor of economics at the Asia-Pacific Institute of Management in New Delhi. 
 Mr. Brown, 34, is the associate director of the Yale-New Haven Teachers Institute, a joint project of the university and the New Haven public schools that provides professional development for teachers. He is also the vice president of the board of Domestic Violence Services of Greater New Haven, and a director of the Greater New Haven Literacy Coalition. He graduated magna cum laude from Yale and received a master's degree in public policy from Harvard. He is a son of Irene Q. Brown and Richard D. Brown of Hampton, Conn. His parents are on the faculty of the University of Connecticut at Storrs. His mother is an associate professor emerita of family studies and of history. His father is the board of trustees distinguished professor of history and the director of UConn's Humanities Institute.

HEADLINE: To the Barricades, Say Foes of Speeding Vans

BYLINE: By JAKE MOONEY

 BODY:
Walk down East 52nd Street near Avenue U in Mill Basin, Brooklyn, and the first things you notice are not the tidy brick houses, the neat hedges or even the giant Kings Plaza Shopping Center and Marina at the end of the block. What you notice first are the vans.
 If you stand on the sidewalk for a minute, chances are good that several 15-foot vans, unmarked vehicles with black-tinted windows, will career down the one-way street. These vehicles, which are on their way to pick up passengers at the mall before speeding back up Flatbush Avenue, are called ''dollar vans'' (though the price of a ride has lately risen to $1.50), and people on East 52nd Street hate them. 
 The vans, an established part of the city's underground economy, are especially popular in parts of Brooklyn and Queens where subway service is limited. Customers maintain that in such areas, the vans, which are run by countless companies, are cheaper and more convenient than mass transit. 
 But people on East 52nd Street object not only to their sheer number and speed. They are also upset by the behavior of the drivers, who, residents say, dump garbage, fight over customers and urinate in the street. One alley on the block bears the handwritten sign, ''Please, this is not a bathroom.''
 Eventually, residents got tired of asking nicely. On several recent weekends they have barricaded the entrance to their block, forcing the vans to take another route. 
 This response, which was first reported by The Brooklyn Skyline, a local weekly, falls into what is at best a legal gray area. But residents describe themselves as addressing a safety issue. ''They speed down the block,'' said one man, who declined to give his name saying he was afraid of antagonizing the van drivers. ''We have children playing over here.'' 
 Some of the vans operate legally, complete with special license plates, but many others do not, which is why residents worry about getting on their wrong side. When one resident confronted a van driver recently, several people said, the driver responded by brandishing a machete.
 Most of the vans are unmarked. One of the few companies whose name was visible on a vehicle near the mall, Alexis Van Line, has no listed telephone number.
 Some drivers have been arrested, and illegal vans have been confiscated, but State Senator Carl Kruger, who represents the area, said neither response had helped. ''They consider it part of doing business,'' he said of the drivers. ''They get arrested, they go through the system, they're back out on the street again in 24 hours in another van.''
 He shrugged off questions about the legality of the barricades. ''We have to try something to get people to understand what we say,'' he said. ''I guess you fight fire with fire.'' JAKE MOONEY


GRAPHIC: Photo: Cheap rides, hassles and in one case, a close look at a machete. (Photo by Angela Jimenez for The New York Times)
