INTERNATIONAL A3-10

Allawi Orders Reopening Of Radical Iraq Newspaper
Prime Minister Iyad Allawi of Iraq ordered the reopening of a radical Shiite newspaper closed by United States soldiers nearly four months ago. The closing was a catalyst for some of the worst anti-American mayhem of the occupation. Dr. Allawi also approved an American airstrike in Falluja. A1

Terrorism Drawing Converts
A growing group of converts to Islam have veered into extremism, raising concerns among antiterrorism officials on both sides of the Atlantic that the new recruits could provide foreign-born Islamic militants with invisibility and cover. A1

3 Americans Face Afghan Court
The three Americans who were arrested by the Afghan police on July 5 for operating an illegal jail in Kabul appeared in court at a preliminary hearing. The men were also charged with robbing, beating and torturing their detainees. A3

Trial Ends Abruptly in Iran
Iran's hard-line judiciary abruptly ended the trial of an intelligence agent charged with killing an Iranian-Canadian photojournalist and said a verdict would come later. Lawyers for her family protested, saying the court had not heard their witnesses' testimony. A7

India Addresses School Safety
The southern Indian state of Tamil Nadu ordered all of its schools to stop holding classes in any room with a thatched roof. It also gave schools one week to remove the roofs, or face closing. The crackdown followed a catastrophic private school fire that killed 90 children. A7

War Crimes Suspected in Sudan
Pro-government militias in the Darfur region of Sudan have been accused of using sexual violence to humiliate black African women and girls as well as the rebels fighting the government in Khartoum. Amnesty International said the attacks amounted to war crimes and crimes against humanity. A9

NATIONAL A11-15

Kerry Campaign Creates Set of Legal Safeguards
Senator John Kerry's campaign is putting together a far more intricate set of legal safeguards than any presidential candidate before him to monitor the election, aides to Mr. Kerry said. A1

9/11 Panel to Lobby Nationwide
Members of the independent Sept. 11 commission say they will mount a nationwide lobbying campaign to press the president and Congress to overhaul the nation's intelligence agencies, an effort they say will begin with a report criticizing the way the government collects and shares intelligence. A13

Edwards Focuses on Economy
John Edwards neared the end of his first week of solo campaigning as John Kerry's running mate by focusing on the economy during three stops in Florida and emphasizing the state's importance to the Democratic campaign. A12

Governor Criticizes Lawmakers
Gov. Arnold Schwarzenegger lashed out at the leaders of the Democratic-dominated Legislature in California, saying the Democrats were too weak to pass the state's budget. A11

Georgia Denies DNA Request
In the first test of a Georgia statute permitting convicts to seek exonerations through DNA test, the state's Supreme Court and the parole board have denied an inmate's request to have his DNA tested. A11

SCIENCE/HEALTH

Study Examines Heart Surgery
A study of heart patients is testing whether sharply increasing the number of heart patients who undergo surgery instead of just taking medication would be beneficial. A1

Drug Test in Alzheimer's Onset
A drug used to treat Alzheimer's disease may briefly delay its onset in people with memory problems that sometimes lead to the disease, researchers reported. A15

NEW YORK/REGION B1-6

City Hot Line to Include Information for Tourists
Just in time for the Republican National Convention, the Bloomberg administration is planning a major expansion of New York City's information hot line, 311, that will allow callers to find out about concerts, museum exhibits, restaurants, theaters and last-minute street closings. B1

Plan to Fight Homelessness
New York City plans to rely on a broadly expanded version of a program that combines new housing with intensive social service to reduce homelessness in the city by two-thirds, as Mayor Bloomberg pledged to do last month. B1

Buffalo's Deficit Battle
Buffalo's overall debt rating since the state imposed a financial control board more than a year ago has been upgraded from negative to stable. But some residents say city budget cuts made in tandem with the takeover may impair crucial services, like police and fire protection. B1

SPORTSMONDAY D1-9

Unknown Takes British Open
Todd Hamilton outlasted Ernie Els in a four-hole playoff and overcame one of the strongest leader boards in recent major golf championship history to beat the odds and capture the 133rd British Open. Mr. Hamilton was ranked 56th in the world. D1

ARTS E1-8

Concerns at Historical Society
Richard Gilder and Lewis E. Lehrman joined the board of the New-York Historical Society a year ago, lent the institution their renowned collection of historical documents and created a $1 million vault to house the archive at their own expense. But some historians and society staff members are concerned the two men are dangling the prize of their collection on the condition that the society go along with their interests. E1

Limit on Radio Commercials
Clear Channel Radio plans to announce that it will limit the number of commercials that its more than 1,200 stations can play, a move that analysts said could ripple through the industry even before it takes effect at the start of next year. C1

A Senate panel has concluded that Riggs Bank executives and bank regulators failed to monitor suspicious financial transactions involving hundreds of millions of dollars. A1

Microsoft's MSN 8 Internet service has finally started to see some profits, after years of losing money in its bid to compete with longtime rival America Online. C1
